content.description: ONLY CLIMBABLE DURING STONE FORT COMPETITION. Just right of The Coven. tart with your left on a good hueco and right on a big undercling in another hueco. Climb straight up.
content.location: Just right of The Coven on the Whitch's Hat boulder

content.description: Sit start with a three finger left-hand sidepull/ undercling pocket. The right hand starting hold is a sloping two finger pocket to the right.Pick some feet and pull up to a shallow pocket and figure out how to get to the good sidepull pocket-pinch up and right. Once here, blast for the lip jug or use some bad intermediates.The landing is slightly sketchy with a drop off to the left and another drop off to the right. The drop off on the right is easily padable for the top section.
content.location: This problem is found in the middle of the aesthetic, featured face. This is one of the first walls visible when approaching the boulderfield from its main entrance.Another way to pinpoint this boulder is to locate the steep classic "Art of Vogi". This problem is on the backside face.The best approach is to hike down the entrance steps, then veer left before the bottom of the hill. There is an established trail uses to access other boulders in the area without hiking in a horseshoe shape.

content.description: Sit start low on a heavily chalked horizontal jug.  Make a roofy traverse right to underclings, then long move straight up to a flat, crescent-shaped edge. Continue up the lieback crack to a committing mantle.
content.protection: This is fairly tall, and a fall from the top is possible, so bring several pads and a good spotter.
content.location: In "The Back Nine", just past Deception, locate a tall, long west facing wall with several problems.  This is the right most problem.

content.description: Start on the obvious crimp jug at chest height. Move left to an assotment of crimps, then up on more small crimps. Tensiony foot-work.
content.location: On the wall facing Ribcage.

content.description:
Hidden from view and with only a single star in the guidebook, this is an easy problem to walk by on your way to nearby 4 star routes.  However, this super steep low ball offers tons of interesting moves, some cool toe-hooks and skin friendly holds. 

  Start on Steamroller underclings then work out the roof making use of some disappointing holds and good toe-hooks. Then follow some good but hard to use edges right along the lip of the roof and topout on Pancake.
content.location: On the roof of the Pancake Boulder.  Right off the trail before Cleopatra.

content.description: Engineer moves to gain the "Wave" and finish to the top.  Feels like V4 once you get the sequence right, and can actually be a good warm up.
content.location: One of the first boulders, just off the main trail.

content.description: start with a high right foot, step up to crimps and shoot for the "watermelon soper"

An unfathomable dyno problem. It is safe to say that if you are under six feet tall, you might have a slight disadvantage. Stand start on good right hand edge and a slightly worse left hand edge. Pick a spot on the giant foot rail and execute a huge move up to a two pad edge. Single clutch is probably the only way to stick the hold. After you take the swing like a hero, match hands and traverse leftwards to the arete using edges before topping out or down climbing.
content.protection:
This landing is slightly worse than its neighbor "Flying High". There is a tree almost directly behind the problem and an uneven slab rising up a few feet behind the problem. 

  A pad party of at least 6 or 7 is highly recommended.
content.location: From  "Tennessee Thong", walk left to the corridor guarded by a large tree. Squeeze into the corridor and the problem is to your left.

content.description:
This line is located at the entrance to a small, dark corridor between two boulders and kind of looks like a warp door in the Galaxy 5000 game.  Although you never dab, take caution not to hit your head if you fall off at the start. 

  Sit start with both hands on a left facing sloper and your feet using a small pocket.  Haul your body off the ground, and slap for a sweet spot on a gritty sloper rail.  Shuffle your hands around, grab some subtle slopers and reach for a decent vertical rail that is followed by some cool fins.  Escape out left following an undercling rail with big feet.
content.location: 10 feet left of Galaxy 5000 on the boulder left of the corridor opening.

content.description: Climb the left side arete on The Frontside boulder (just around the corner from Celestial Mechanics and the Dragon problems).
content.location: Left arete of The Frontside boulder

climbs.name: Vulcans Do It With Straight Faces

content.description: On the boulder to the left as you are right next to the Shiver Me Timbers Boulder is a short pocketed bulge to clab.  Start with left in bowling ball grip and right on thin pockets.  Move up to obvious jug pocket, then mantle out the slab above.
content.protection: Crashpads and Spotters and Tape for fingers
content.location: The Back Nine: Tee Box Area

content.description: "Sit start on low rail left of the Shining on jugs. Climb up good holds to right-facing dihedral and crack feature to top out that can feel awkward without attention to footwork.
content.location: Frumundathunda Boulder

content.description: Sit start at a jug and move up to a sloper top out.
content.location: The fourth line from the left (second from the right) on the last boulder in the field.

content.description: Follow the jugs and edges up the arete where Bosley Traverse begins going upward.
content.location: Starts on the red jug ledge at the base of the arete that Bosley Traverse ends up going to. Tops out as does Bosley Traverse.

content.description: Stand start and climb on good edges to the top.
content.location: Second line from the left on the last boulder in the field.

content.description: hand sized crack around the corner from Main Event and just right of Formula1.
content.location: Slice and Dice Boulder.  Around the corner from Main Event and Tucan Sam.  Just right of Formula 1

content.description: Stand start in pockets under the roof and move to the top on good edges.
content.location: The leftmost line on the last boulder in the field.

content.description:
Guidebook has two different v0s listed here with the same finish, I actually found them both a littler harder than Funhouse (v1) to their left.

 Version 1: Climb up the center of the boulder on great holds below the hueco, top out into the hueco, then walk off.

 Version 2: Climb the small crack on the right with some trickier moves down low, then go up and traverse left into the same hueco on top, then top out.
content.location: The two lines just right of funhouse, all three finishing in the same hueco topout thingy.

content.description: Start as low as you can on the right, and traverse across the lip on good hands using heel hooks and small/smearing feet, top out just before the crack thing about halfway across the boulder.
content.location: where the boulder is about 2' tall it starts, and continues across as the boulder grows in height

climbs.name: Up High, Down Low, Too Slow

content.description: A proud crimp, balance and power test-piece. Sit start matched on a small crimp chip. the left side is a small incut tooth for 2 or 3 fingers. Pull on with a slight toe cam out right and reach down to an undercling in order to paste a left foot. From here stand up tall and press off the left hand for a full span move to a very thin gaston before doing a very tight hand foot match on the start hold in order to gain jugs on the lip of the boulder.
content.location: This is the incredible looking line about five feet right of  "Castaway".

content.description: Starts on a jug, then climb up a featured face to a topout.
content.location: You'll find this on the Fish Market Boulder. Go to were Fish Market Traverse is, and just to the right you'll see a good hueco, that's the start.

content.description:
Start in obvious jugs around the corner left from The Fish Market and low, right of Unusual Suspect. Go straight up.

 Route is just "V3" in the latest Stone Fort guidebook, so I decided to give it a name.
content.location: Right of Unusual Suspect, left and down from The Fish Market

content.description: party trick offwidth squirm job while your bouldering friends finesse up "Fame."
content.location: just left of Fame

content.description:
A friction dependent problem, maybe try this one on an overcast day.

 Squat start matched on a sloping rail with a few pocket features in it. Pull onto the wall using a low and obvious foot and make a hard deadpoint up to a good hold. Latch it then get the feet up before moving to slopers at the lip of the boulder, a reachy bump or a hard surf out gains better holds and then the top out.
content.protection: 2 pads and a spotter. A punt from the top could possibly be painful.
content.location: This problem is located on the wall behind "Sternum". It is also located a few feet left of "The White Face" and it is technically the stand start to "Tyrone Biggums".

content.description: Start out on underclings and make long move up to jug. Make more powerful moves to same finish as SuperMario
content.location: On the far side of SuperMario boulder

content.description: on the left side of the boulder, climb the right side of the flakes
content.location: Your sister's boulder

content.description: ONLY CLIMBABLE DURING THE STONE FORT COMPETITION. Climb straight up using good dishes to finish on a weird topout.
content.location: The Big Mike boulder

content.description:
Located on the Shiver Me Timbers Boulder in the Back Nine, you pass right under this one you way to Shiver, Deception, the Shield, ect. Starts in a slot and moves right through slopy iron bands and sidepulls to good crimps just under the lip before you pull the roof.  

  There's and birds nest under the roof that's regulalry occupied so catch this problem in the colder temps when the nest is vacant. If occupied, don't be a dick and leave the problem for another day.
content.protection: Pads. The landing is rocky and there's backsplat potential.

content.description: Climb the slab just to the right of the arete. Starts with an undercling pocket. Smear and slap your way to the top.
content.location: Space/Odyssey Area

content.description: Start on jugs and climb up to a crescent shaped hand jam to the top.
content.location: Slice and Dice Boulder.  To the right of Slice.

content.description: Climbs parallel grooves in a beautiful face.  The cracks are somewhat insecure, and it can be hard to see your holds, but the topout is pretty easy.
content.location: In the "Back Nine" area, on the "Graham Crackers" Boulder. This line follows parallel crack/grooves up the South face of the boulder.  Begin near the top of the slab, just right of a block.

content.description: This traverse moves through the large holds underneath the top of the boulder. Start on the far right side and move left towards Turtle Tracks Direct, then straight up to mantle. Low to the ground, so keep the core tight to not dab in the ground. This has some tricky moves and I found it to be much more interesting than the other two turtle tracks problems
content.location: Turtle Tracks boulder

content.description: The shorter, sweeter version of turtle tracks: take the direct line up the mantle.  You could sit start, but the main point is getting over the mantle using a solid heel hook on the obvious spot.  a good lowball to practice mantle techniques.  it taught me how to mantle and heel hook!  a great teacher
content.protection: possibly pad and spotter as there is a large rock just to the left and your head could fall right on it if your heel slips, although it is short

content.description: Start on the right side of this super short boulder, pretty much laying down. One move to the lip, then traverse all the way left to top it out
content.location: Front Area: Turtle Tracks Boulder

content.description: Three opening moves on sharp crimps and a high heel hook lead to much easier terrain. Destined to never be done again.
content.location: This climb is on the blunt arete just left of Cyclops.

content.description: This problem is very fun. Everyone does it differently. Some dyno, others can somehow find finger locks. Fun problem and a must do!
Start on a low left hand crimp and a sidepull in the crack. Work up using the obvious face holds and the even more obvious crack. Physical crux is at the beginning, mental crux is near the top.
content.protection: Handful of pads and a spotter. It's a highball.
content.location: Just to the left of Kaya. Climb straight up the beautiful hand crack.

content.description: Single move dyno problem on the Psychosomatic boulder. I'm not usually into throws, but this one is really fun. Big holds to big holds with an easy topout.
content.location: On the Psychosomatic boulder, directly across from the Celestial Mechanics/Dragon Corridor.

content.description: Start on the same holds as for Trailer Hitch but instead of a dyno use the arete and top out at the peak.
content.location: At the main area on the Phillips Fury boulder.

content.description: From the Wellman guidebook: Starts just to the right of a large tree on a flat shelf. Start matched, then traverse right using shallow pockets and a heel hook to gain the pockets of Blind Spot. Finish up using shallow brushed sloper and holds on Blind Spot.
content.location: On the Blind Spot boulder.

content.description: Start on the pedestal and climb the crack left to right.
content.location: Two shoes jack boulder.

content.description: Start laying on your back with hands on the low crimp rail. Slap your way up the arete and top out once you hit the lip. Crux for me was sticking the first move.
content.location: This boulder sits below the boulder with art of vogi. There are some slab problems to the left of it.

content.description: Sit start same as for Rail Rider. Climb straight up the arête to a slopey top out.
content.location: In the Back Nine. Climb Graham Crackers then pull the crash pad back a few feet to the start of this climb.

content.description: Start at the arete to the left of Mystery Groove.  Use one hand on each side of the arete to smear and reach up to the jugs at the top.
content.location: Mystery Groove Boulder.

content.description: Climb arete, via big moves and a hard mantle to finish.
content.location: Located on the Frumundathunda boulder, just down the trail from Galaxy 5000.

content.description: The slab to the right of the corner hand crack. Stand start and climb the slab using incuts and pockets, avoiding the crack to the left
content.location: In the Crack of Doom area across from Pocket Pool

content.description: Start low near the middle of the wall and traverse up and left grabbing two particularly mammorific slopers and mantle up on them.
content.location: On the Your Sister Boulder.  Just down from Cinderella and Cleopatra.

content.description:
get a running start.

 The guidebook rates this as "v?" it's a fun little thing to do if you're into these kinds of fun little things.
content.location: the blankest and tallest part of the slab on the dumb luck boulder, sorta facing super mario

content.description: SDS on a large side pull under the roof near the fence, move up to the triangular corner, then left to a good crimp then up to a marginal slopes, and finally the flat jug at the top.
content.location: Front Area, Swingers Boulder

content.description: Highball Crack climb
content.location: Located on the backside of the Mystery Groove Boulder, facing the Spyro Gyro Wall.

content.description: Pointy triangular boulder that looks like a T-Bone. Start on flat edge with both hands and squeeze up to the jug fin at the top. Step off.
content.location: Just to the right of Diatribe in the Human Chew Toy area

content.description: Stand start on jugs. Move straight up underneath the mini roof then traverse right on the seam to the top out.
content.location: Essentially the middle of the funhouse boulder.

content.description: Begin way back in the cave either on the sketchy chockstone or on the jug rail left of it.  Climb out the cave on monster jugs.  A moderate topout puts you on the top of the Swingers boulder.
content.protection: Crashpad and possibly a spotter for the topout.
content.location: On the Swingers boulder down and left from Tennessee Thong and Tall Tee.

content.description: Start on Super Mario. After completing the crux, go straight up to the two crimps up left (instead of traversing out right). Some huck for the high jug, while others figure out static beta. Super fun!The bailing to the right beta, climbing bucket jugs to the highest jug, make it feel easier than than the guidebook grade of V6.
content.protection: A few pads make things less sketchy.  Thankfully there are usually crowds around this boulder.
content.location: Same start as Super Mario, finish high.

content.description: "Knee bar"  Don't miss the knee bar on this problem or it just might become one or two grades harder.
content.location: Just before the Back 9. On the Super Mario boulder.

content.description: I figured I would add this in because it is the way Sunnie Rose goes and keeps the V5 grade. Pretty neat and challenging at the grade too. Instead of going out right, head directly straight up on thin holds and a tiny pocket until you reach the better holds above.
content.location: Same as for Sunnie Rose, but don't bail right. If the holds feel thin, you're in the right place.

content.description: Sit start is chalked up pockets up to a huge left jug. From here up to a slopey jug out right and a ghaston out left. Stand up and lock off to a throw out right to a positive half jug. Now work feet to the right and rock over to another sweet slopey jug.
content.location: The Destroyer Boulders right on the edge of the golf course just below the Super Mario area.

content.description: Start on ledge rail just right of tree. Up to slopers to mantle finish
content.location: In the Entrance Area, on the "Bowling Ball" boulder, adjacent to the Firecrack boulder.

content.description: Sit start on orange crimpers. Move up and left on good sloper and jug rails before making a reachy and tensiony move out left to good holds. Finish up the easy arete to top out.
content.location: Go left around the corner from Fat Cat and Thundafrummunda and through the narrow opening to find a relatively hidden problem. Note that the ground here is often wet.

content.description: I've seen this called V1, but I thought it was a sandbag at that.  This climbs the really cool wall topped by castle-like parapets. The crux is at the very top, so be solid, or use a rope.
content.location: In the Entrance Area, on the castle wall.

content.description: Same start as Ribcage problem. Climb out right through the roof to slopey holds and top out on the other side of arete.
content.location: The Corridors Area, Ribcage Boulder

content.description: If you don't like tiny holds, this is the route for you.  Start on big jug underclings under the roof and pull your butt of the rock. Move out the roof to an easy mantle.  The crux is not hitting the rock.
content.location: Located in the old "Main Area", between the Brian's Bain boulder and Cleopatra on the "Pancake" boulder (look for the distinctive pancake feature). Climbs the left side of the boulder.

content.description: Step onto the low shelf/feet using any pebbles or balance you can muster and maintain "The Stand" for a FULL 5 seconds.  If you get it right you can stand there forever.  Stone Fort Comp guide calls it a V3.
content.location: Directly to the Right of Crack of Doom.  Look for a vertical wall that curls back slightly with a couple of small pebbles on it.  There is a large shelf and a couple smaller feet.

content.description: Stand start on a jug about 4.5 feet off the ground. Pull on and reach up to the crescent shaped hold up and left. From here, use your best judgement on how to grab the shelf 4 feet higher than the crescent. Once here match hands and decide how to top it out.
Similar to Spare (v0), Split starts just to the right, and heads straight up, doing similar moves. Another great moderate on one of the best single boulders in the area.
content.location: Right of Spare, left of Gutter Ball (v2).

content.description: Balancey problem that starts two hands on obvious chalky, slopey rail. Mantle on the starting rail to stand up then top out.
content.location: This is in the narrow back alley from Space, leading to Midway and Shotgyn.

content.description: One of the best V0's around, in that, you actually have to think about the moves.  As you climb, keep in mind that this is also the descent for the boulder.
content.location: In the Entrance Area, on the "Bowling Ball" boulder, adjacent to the Firecrack boulder.

content.description: Sit start on two good edges, then move up the wall with many sequence options between a few bad holds.  High topout, but the climbing eases.
content.location: In the old "Main Area", in a small shaded corridor with "Latin for Daggers" and "The Law".  This climbs the brilliant orange sweep on slopey crimps.

content.description:
Besides it's diminutive stature and a tree that chose to grow in an unfortunate place, this problem offers high-quality rock, sculpted holds and fun moves. 

  Sit start on good pockets.  Left hand goes to a horrible hold, slap the arete to the right, and top out on slopers.  Just don't dab the tree that sits directly behind you.
content.location: In the Super Mario Area.  Just downhill from Super Mario Boulder.

content.description: In the corridor about 10 feet right of Space.  Stand start and climb very pocketed face to easy top out.  Traverse left along the shelf past the top of Space to get off.
content.location: Space Odyssey Area: Space Boulder

content.description: Stand start with left on low side pull and right on shallow pocket. Move left gaining small pocket and finish at obvious jug. The top of it is usually wet, so I'm making it a drop down problem. Topping it would probably add another grade or two. This entire boulder is not in any of the books and its hard to believe that it hasn't been climbed before, however, there's no information on any of the beta sites about the lines I put up, so I'll be claiming them as FA's, so I can share with everyone on this site and hopefully make it to the next edition of the book along with other even better developed lines out there. Stay tuned for more and let me know what you think about the climb or if you know anyone who has done this problem before. Enjoy!
content.location: This problem is located on the blank boulder located left of Space and Odyssey. and across from Two Shoes Jack.

content.description: Climb the blank slab with two small pockets on the left side of the Space Odyssey Area.
content.protection: More than one pad and a spotter or two.  Watch out for toe pops and face drag!
content.location: From the from the Front Area take the trail that goes up the hill on the right.  Walk around the corner on the left and you will be in the Space Odyssey Area.

content.description: Stand start on good edges in a horizontal break and move up to the "South America" feature. Climb the feature up and right to larger holds and top out on the slab.
content.location: In the Crack of Doom area, in the corridor that goes to Grimace; accross the corridor from Pocket Pool.

content.description: Start via The Fish Market, traverse right into Soapmakers, and finish via Soapmakers. Fun little extension to a great problem that, in my opinion, is just harder enough than Soapmakers to warrant V3
content.location: Starting on starting slopes to The Fish Market, traverse left and finish via Soapmakers,

content.description: The brassy little sucker on the Fish Market boulder. About 5 feet right of Fish Market, grab some edges, and work your way right into some slopers, then do an HP40 mantle onto blankness. Great way to practice your (almost) holdless topouts low to the ground.    Also just a fun little climb.
content.location: 5 feet right of Fish Market, v4

content.description: This is a nice slab problem on the N face of the boulder.  Start between trees, climb up and right towards the big crack/groove.
content.location: On the "Spit Shine" boulder, in the "Back Nine", next to the "Graham Crackers" and "Shiver Me Timbers" boulders.

content.description: Sit start on jugs under roof to the right of Swingers.  Move out flat holds to the top.  DO NOT USE the "XX" flake.
content.location: Front Area: Swingers Boulder

content.description: Same start as Dragon Lady.Then it moves left to seam. Climb to the top.
content.location: Next to the classic line Dragon Lady.

content.description: Right where the trail from Space and Odyssey meet the back cliff line is a clean low angle slab.  The problem climbs up the left side.
content.location: Space Odyssey Area: Space Boulder: Corridor behind the Space and Odyssey Boulders, on the back wall.

content.description: Start sitting with the right hand on a good crimp rail in the oval hueco feature, and the left hand either matched or underneath on an undercling . Pull on to the wall with some large feet at the base of the overhang, and traverse left using a few sloping crimp features. From here move further left into "Pure Rock Fury" using underclings and a nice sloper, and fire a crux move for a good hold up and left. Top out up and slightly right. The topout is a bit hairy at first until figured out. Once established on the large ledge of the boulder you can downclimb by following the slabby ramp to the right.
content.protection: 3 pads. A spotter for the sloping top helps.
content.location: This problem starts in the middle of the short overhang. It is located next to the corridor leading to the "Now and Zen Area".

content.description: Classic arete!  A couple nice moves squeezing the arete on the R and pulling pockets on the L gains a huge sidepull groove/crack up high.
content.location: L side of Two Shoes Jack arete.  Space and Odessey corridor will be to your back.

content.description: This one climbs like the crimper problem on your home woody. On the right-hand side of the short overhanging face.  Sit start low on crimps in hueco and move up to more crimps finishing left at the top.
content.location: On the fish lips boulders, opposite of Now and Zen (V7)

content.description: Start at the jug and climb up crimpers to a slope-y top-out.
content.location: Slice and Dice Boulder

content.description: Really slopey route! Start low. Traverse left to a fun topout.
content.location: Tri-Star Boulder, Area 51.

content.description: Friction slab left of the Brian's Brain downclimb. Get used to the LRC rock by padding your way up and down this thing and you should be ready for the next step.
content.location: Left side of the slab that also holds the Brian's Brain downclimb.

content.description: Starts on the left side of the face at a shallow left faint dihedral. SDS and climb direct to a break in the face, climb past this up the tall but featured face to the to pout. Highball.
content.protection: Pads, and spotters would be a good idea.
content.location: Sternum Area - Bonesaw Area

content.description: From a sloper jug and undercling, pull several more undercling moves with a high step or two mixed in, to better holds up and right to the top.  A little awkward.
content.location: Mystery Machine Boulder, left of MM and RR.

content.description: Stand start left of arête on good holds. Mantle to right side of arête and go for the triangle pinch at the top!
Stand start using the obvious left hand sidepull pocket in smooth face. Climb up the face using a series of edges close to Clutch for the right, eventually gaining the vertical crack.
content.location: On the Phillip's Fury Boulder to the left of Clutch

content.description: Sit start on two small crimps under the overhang. Figure a way to reach the jug up and right of the start and then work your way up the two parallel water grooves to the top.
content.location: Located just right of Jerry's Kids in the Jungle Gym area.

content.description: Great holds, including a cool pocket and some slopers. A nice clear line on great rock. Not so high that it's dangerous.
content.location: When facing the Mystery Machine, v3, look around the corner to the right for a 10' boulder that start on edges, works through a pocket. Right of tree, left of wide crack.

content.description: Stand start, climb the arete to the right of the tree on really pebbly rock via open hand grips and jugs.
content.location: Mystery groove boulder around the corner from mystery groove.

content.description: Good pockets with bad feet
content.location: on the boulder behind galaxy 5000

content.description: What a gorgeous climb. It's too bad the climb to the right is marked up with giant X's. Start on a jug. Move up on jugs. Make a big reach to a nice incut hold. Figure out the top on slopers and jugs.
content.location: Up the hill past Ribcage and Sternum. Look for a swirly orange rock cave thing.

content.description: Start on obvious lowest slot on good, but sharp incut crimps. Make a hard move to another incut crimp with right hand, then make another powerful move up the face to good holds at the lip. Top out using slopers and pinches.
content.protection: A pad to cover the rock slab behind you. A spotter is nice to have as well.
content.location: The clean face opposite Graham Cracker and The Shield.

content.description: A big move between sharp but good crimps, followed by some easier finishing moves.
content.location: In the "Back Nine" area, on the first boulder encountered on the trail, across from the obvious "Graham Crackers" Boulder. Sit start on the right side of the face, matched on a big crimp, head up and right.

content.description: On right side of the boulder
content.location: Your sister's boulder

content.description: This problem has got to be one of the best in the world! The movement is amazing and the boulder is beautiful! To begin, you start on two jugs to the right under the bulge. Start working your way out left on crimps, finishing on a double gaston.
content.location: Obvious line on the bulge of the Graham Cracker boulder.

content.description: Start on the pink blob on the corner, and work your way up and left. A tad licheny, and you're still doing real climbing all the way near the top, so do bother to drag some pads under you.    One of the 20+ great climbs on the Mystery Machine boulder <v4.
content.protection: 2 pads if you plan on falling from up there.
content.location: All the way on the right on the face that holds Mystery Machine, on the Mystery Machine boulder.

content.description: Climb the rightward angling seam to the left of the big detached flake. Stand start on crimpers by the seam and climb crimps and sidepulls up the seam and using the left arete to the top.  You have to ignore the good holds further left.
content.location: Front Area: Fire Crack Boulder

content.description: Stand start. Mantle scoop feature and climb incuts to the break. Downclimb V0- slab to the right.
content.location: Sternum boulder. Looking at Ribcage, look for the obvious scoop feature around the arete to the left.

content.description: A dirty, slab route on the Brain Boulder. Start matched on a good jug in the middle of the face. Move out right to a good rail and up to a large, muddy pocket. Get a good foot and move up left to a side pull rail. Follow crimps to the top. Slap a high right foot up on the right edge of the top and mantle onto a dirty top out. Walk around the boulder to the right and hop onto the wave boulder to get down. Beware of thorns.
content.location: Located on the Brain Boulder in the Front Area of LRC. This route is almost directly across from Fire Crack Flake (V1). This boulder is probably the dirtiest in the Front Area.

content.description: Step up onto boulder using low horizontal cracks, climb up onto the ledge and either climb straight up the face or step up and R onto the slab.
content.protection: Pad and spotter, some potential for bad falls, but landing is pretty good.
content.location: Boulder to the R of Cyclops, this climb starts to the R of the tree climbing up onto a shelf 4' up.

content.description: ONLY CLIMBABLE DURING STONE FORT COMPETITION. Start low with your right on the right face sloper and your left in a large pocket. Climb straight up and top out slightly left.
content.location: To the right around the corner from El Camino

content.description: A delightful techy little boulder on the backside of the Heartbreaker/Mystery Groove boulder. Work your way from a good side pull up and through wee pockets to a faith-testing stand-up.    Would be 4 stars, but it doesn't get a lot of traffic, and it's a little overgrown.
content.protection: 1 pad and a spotter. Pretty safe stuff, though.
content.location: Backside of the Heartbreaker/Mystery Groove boulder. Right across from Storming the Castle, v1, left of a tree. Work up between 2 runnels.

content.description: Climb sloping side pulls directly up the face to better holds and a fun top out.
content.location: Mystery Machine Boulder, left of Mystery Machine

content.description: A problem that climbs taller than it looks.  Start the same as Daddy Loves on the large pink jugs and traverse left into Roscoe; climb the seam feature up the short face
content.location: Front Area: Daddy Loves Boulder

content.description: Stand Start left side of the boulder and climb the seam.
content.location: Daddy loves boulder

content.description: Lowball traverse. Sit start on jugs down and left of the Tooth Fairy start rail. Make a big move past a tree to gain that rail, then continue right. The new guide says to top out more on the the face, but some people keep traversing a few moves to top out the same as Diesel Power, I don't think it really makes a difference.

The right arete on the backside of the Chronic Boulder.  

  Sit start with both hands on a low ripple on the arete.  Left facing slopers, tenuous heel hooks, and some tricky beta gains the big undercling at the end of Left Wing.  Reach up to a horrible sloper, and thrutch yourself onto the slab.   

  It's low stature and flat landing make this a good option for bouldering alone.
content.location: On the backside of the Chronic boulder.

content.description: Climb the right side arete while leaning left. Wall on right side is off.
content.location: The right arete of a short detached block in a corner on the back wall behind and left of the Bowling Ball boulder. On the Cornerstone boulder

content.description: Start on the pinch and climb up the roof to a slopey mantle. Don't go far right.
content.location: On the Ribcage Boulder.

content.description: A very nice long slab with interesting moves on cool holds and an exciting finish. Before you hurry up to a spot you can't downclimb from, remember that there is a difference between V1 and V0.
content.location: In the "Back Nine", hike on the main trail past "Deception" and "White Trash" into a shady/mossy corridor.  The "Mono Doigt" wall is on the left side of the corridor (East Facing) toward the end as it opens up. This problem is on the left side of the wall on a long clean slab.

content.description: Climb the long funky runnel on the boulder to the climber's right of the "Your Sister Boulder."  You can leave the gimmicks at home but some slab and crack technique will go a long ways.
content.protection: A few pads and spotters as the landing on this one could cause some damage.
content.location: Down off of the trail as for the "Your Sister Boulder" or just after the tall faces near "Cinderella" and "Cleopatra."  Look for the tall obvious runnel.

content.description: A nice long problem, but not the best rock or most interesting moves. Sit start low (which seems excessive on such a long problem, but these are the hardest moves). Make some tough moves on sharp crimps, then continue up and slightly right on easier climbing.  The top out may be a bit dirty, so be careful.
content.protection: Several pads and a good spotter.
content.location: In the old Main Area, on the Tanqueray boulder (the same boulder Spanky is on. This is on the left side of the tall North face of the boulder, facing the main area towards Brians Bain.

content.description:
Stand start on a left hand thin crimp and right hand gaston in a slopey seam about five feet off the ground. Pull onto the wall and lockoff up to a left hand sloper crimp. From here get a super high foot and do a hard lockoff to a bad hold. Lockoff as far as you can and bump up to a big but slopey sidepull. Once here dyno up to a sloper or do a hard foot cross through before reaching up. Finish up on good holds. 

  The slopey sidepull is pretty reachy, although shorter folks may be able to get a higher right foot.
content.protection: 3 pads and a spotter. There is a rock slab rising up behind this problem.
content.location:
This problem is located directly behind "Mane Event" in the corridor.  

  It is also to the right of "I Think I Can".

content.description: Start on jugs and move up on good holds to the top.
content.location: On the Fish Market Boulder - start just right of a tree on jugs at the left side of the face.

content.description: Start same as The Red House, but move up past pockets via sidepull/crimps and top out approx. 7 feet above the original finish. Don't be afraid to throw for the final jug (you're not coming off it). The extension makes the problem way better IMO.
content.protection: A couple crash pads and a spotter or two
content.location: Super Mario boulder

content.description: Sit start on small underclings just right of Super Mario. Find the right feet and pull a difficult move to a sloping rail. Continue climbing up and gain the incut crimps on Super Mario. Move right finishing up on Super Mario.
content.location: Super Mario Boulder

content.description: Begin low and climb the rail up and right to the topout.
content.location: Spit Shine boulder. On the Back Nine.

content.description: The obvious overhanging prow on the back side of the Super Mario Boulder.  Odd start through a roof on decent holds with kneebars and/or heel hooks with a nice dynamic crescendo and slopey topout.
content.location: On the backside of the Super Mario Boulder.  Next to Fury.

content.description:
Start sitting with your left hand in a good undercling pocket and your right in a not as good undercling pocket. Pull a long move to a decent rail, then up again, and finish left. 

  One can climb up to the second break and then traverse off right. Or, after establishing yourself (standing) at the first break, downclimb and jump down.
content.location:
In the Fish Lips area. Just to the right of the dark corridor that leads to the Now and Zen area. 

  There are two prominent problems on this piece of rock. Pure Rock Fury is the left of these two lines. The other is about 15 feet to the right.

content.description: Start pinched on a decent hold and your left hip turned in with left foot on a small hold. Use either the seam above the starting hold or a slopey break in the rock to get your left foot out wide and make a long move up and left to a bad pocket/pinch. After you stick the sloper at the break you have it in the bag. Top out up and right on jugs.
content.location: Main Area, right off the trail when you enter the vicinity of Celestial Mechanics/Dragon Lady/Spanky.

content.description: Sit start with left hand in the undercling and right hand on the sloper. Power straight up, bulgy at first, via sloping jugs to crimpy rails at top.
content.location: The Cell Area, just beyond The Law(V11) roof is a corridor to the left

content.description: Sit start on the jug at the base of the blunt arete and climb it until you can transition to the right side of the arete to top out.
content.location: On the back cliff line in the Moss Man area. The blunt arete next to Human Chew Toy 5.11d.

content.description: Climb interesting pockets to a cool mantle in an unattractive face. The line to the left is V7.
content.location: On the "Crack of Doom" boulder, which is just south of the old "Main Area". From Crack of Doom, walk around left to a short pocketed face left of a tree.

content.description: Pretty good climbing, but the landing is a bit crappy with the step off. Maybe an erosion issue? Super Mario is the most ticked boulder on MP in this entire entire.
content.protection: 2 pads and a spotter so you don't pitch down the hill if you fall.
content.location: The slopey arete feature on the boulder just left of Super Mario. Look for it just before heading downhill.

content.description: Short, but packs a fingery little punch. Start sitting on small holds, and shoot up to some little guys until you are on decent slopers at 8 feet. Then delicately work through the rest of the tallish face on somewhat dirty rock.    Not the greatest climbing around, but it feels pretty good to execute on it.
content.protection: 1 pad. nice to have a spot on the tall dirty finish.
content.location: Just around the corner from Graham Crackers, on the Shield boulder. Look for the steep undercut with small holds.

content.description: The fun rail on the Castaway boulder that isn't Mizzen Mast, v1. Suffers only from the fact that the feet are quite bad, so it's easy to skate all over the place. Well, and that one often climbs Mizzen Mast right after it, which is an incredible v1, so this one feels like it wasn't very good.    Actually it is.
content.protection: 2 pads to cover whole landing area. Really safe.
content.location: Look for this fella around the corner to the right of Castaway, on the opposite side of the boulder as Mizzen Mast.

content.description: Stand start at the base of the large proud arete and follow it up utilizing the large features then start to trend leftwards on decent holds.
content.location: Same Boulder as "Sunnie Rosie". You can't miss this arete.

content.description: To the left of The Glove V5. Climb the neat prow feature. Start standing left on good sidepull, right on bad sloper pocket. Make an awkward move to the hidden jug on the right and top out trending left.
content.location: In the Pit. Behind Art of the Vogi

content.description: An odd line. Opens with a good couple of moves, medium-powerful, then traverses right through slopers and crimps to a balancey, but not as difficult, rockover.    Start seated hands on the cool jug rail that will be at face height. Shoot up left to your choice of pinches, and then right into the traverse. When people say "the pinch" I think they are talking about the slopier, higher one, but I thought it felt a lot better to just skip that hold, and make a longer reach out right from the lower left hand. Using that thing felt kind of forced. Maybe I didn't get full value of the boulder problem without that hold?   It does make sense to traverse right and rockover, sure, but wouldn't it make some sense to climb it straight up? There are definitely some holds there, though they would take some effort to clean. In any event, this boulder has 2 really fun moves (that make it definitely worth doing) at the beginning, and then a decent traverse.   This is the most question marks I've ever put in one problem description. So yeah, an odd line.
content.protection: 2-3 pads and a spotter. Landing slopes back while you are traversing, and it would be nice to have a spot in the event of a fall on this section.
content.location: Left of Cinderella and Cleopatra, there is a squat little wall with a short steep section of chalked holds and an obvious series of left hand pinches.

content.description: SDS on a rail or use the two in-cut holds near the rail.  Pull the start with a big move to a sloping crimp and a left hand under cling.  Use sloping side pulls and "Loaf" feature to gain jugs and top out.
content.location: Located just right of Boogie Man-tle, on the Mystery Machine boulder.

content.description: Get in the man sized hueco. Have someone take your picture. You can really put this in the v-fun category but the mantelish moves to get in are still climbing. Would be fun to see other folks pictures posted up here.
content.protection: Pad is nice for jumping out.
content.location: Originally thought it was back nine. Right near Super Mario.

content.description: An incredible arete climb unknown by the masses.Stand start the overhanging arete in the tight corridor with a right hand pinch and left hand edge. Paste some feet and power up the arete on fin-like holds. After a few moves, rockover onto the slab and layback the arete with tension and balance. Reach a good horizontal, then continue the balancy tension on the arete and slopes to the top.An awesome and full value line.
content.location: This problem's downfall is its tight location. It is found just past the main area containing "Sternum", "Crack of Doom", "White Face" and "Ribcage". From the obvious vertical crack called "Crack of Doom" walk ten yards then turn left into the large alcove with "Mouse Crack" and the obscure "Team 87". This problem is found on the left of the slabby wall.The slab behind this climb is avoidable and this slab along with the tree could potentially be hazardous if an unexpected or uncorrected fall happened.

content.description: SDS on jugs, gain "Pancake" feature, mantle over the "Pancake"

climbs.name: Out of Africa (AKA A Face in the Crowd)

content.description:
A great problem that is hard to find, but always in the shade.  Start on your but and use tricky footwork while following sharp crimps up and right.  Try to avoid using the surrounding boulders. 

  Opposite this problem is Grimace, a v8/9 that climbs up a rounded arete on slopers.
content.location: In the corridors area (about 150 yards from the entrance). Locate the "Crack of Doom".  Walk around to the left of the crack into a corridor that leads to a cave.  This problem will be on your right when you enter the cave, on the backside of the Crack of Doom boulder.  Start on big holds with a right undercling and left jug.

content.description: Sit Start on the lowest chalked hold. Find feet under the low roof and make strong opening moves. Find your way to a jug rail (V3 Stand start from here) and continue on good holds making a few long moves. Steep top-out on good rounded holds.
content.protection: Pad and spotter. Watch the boulder behind you.
content.location: Jerry's Kids Boulder in the Jungle Gym Area

content.description: Start the same as Monster climb up and L on crimps, mantle under the Cyclops Boulder.
content.protection: spotter and pad would be good forthis tricky finish
content.location: "Monster Boulder" behind cyclops

content.description: Starts on chalked up rail to the right of Tennessee Thong and move straight up the roof to slopers. Find a way to hit the jug and enjoy the easy top-out. Watch out for the fence!
content.location: Furthest right line on the Tennessee Thong boulder. The start is obvious.

content.description: Sit start low on a good left hand pinch/undercling and bad right hand crimp. Make a hard move with bad feet up to bread loaf pinch jug, then mantle to the top.
content.location: In the Entrance area on the Wave Boulder.  This is the Southeast arete of the boulder.

content.description: Start low on a few interesting holds and move up on pinches, crimps, and sidepulls to top out up and right.
content.location: Located in the Now and Zen area, up in a corridor.  It is just right of Dr. Atkinson

content.description: Start on giant iron flakes, and climb directly up, following the vertical seam. Tall and a little sketchy.
content.location: Graham Cracker boulder, on the face around the corner from the Graham Cracker problem facing the fairway. Far right side of the face.

content.description: A proud slab climb with barely enough holds to make it up. Stand start on some giant sloper jugs, and figure out how to reach the slot/ gaston about five and a half feet up and slightly left. The crux is the next move getting to the flat lip up and left. Top out in easier terrain.
content.location: The back 9 just before "Biggie Shorty"  on the left.

content.description: The brown face covered in large flakey holds is a very popular first problem of the day.  Stand start and climb straight up from the bottom and finish left.
content.location: Front Area: Fire Crack Boulder

content.description: Start just to the left of a tree.  Climb up the scoop via side pulls, gastons and some thinking to the jugs at the top.
content.location: Mystery Machine Boulder.

content.description: Classic! Start on jugs and go up the groove using the sidepulls and pinches.
content.location: On the Mystery Groove Boulder. Stand start.

content.description: Fun climb just to the right of Easy Does it (where most people use to down climb after topping out).  Thin face climb. The middle part was little reachy for me.
content.location: It's on the back of the Mystery Machine Boulder, to the right of Easy Does It (V0-), and to the left of I Think I Can (V9).

content.description: One of two fantastic v0s on the backside of the Mystery Groove boulder. This is the left one, characterized by pebbly jugs. Great for a first romp of the day.
content.location: 6 feet left of Five and Dime, the right hand v0 on the Mystery Groove boulder on the face directly across from Storming the Castle, v1.

content.description: A beautiful crack with a horrible landing.
content.location: corridors

content.description: SDS and climb the face using small edges and sidepulls.  An obvious jug about 12 feet up ends the difficult climbing and most people down climb from there.
content.location: On the right side of the Barometer wall which is located near the Dragon Lady corridor on the way to Super Mario etc.

content.description: Sit start on sloper jugs with a right heel. Move up to sharp crimp, and then left to crimp rail. Use left-hand sidepulls to gain the jug. Most people drop from here, but the top out is possible and easy.
content.protection: One or two pads and a spotter.
content.location: Just past the Main Area on the Barometer Wall. Look for a razor sharp crimp at about 4 feet.

content.description: Conglomerate covered in moss can't be fun, can it? Well, yes. Yes it can. Stand start in a large pocket on the Moss Man boulder to the left of High Tide. Continue on pockets to crimps and a cruiser top out.
content.protection: A couple pads and a spotter might be nice.
content.location: Moss Man boulder

content.description: Start on the left side of the face on a big flake jug, then traverse right on incuts to join Monster. The additional moves aren't too hard, so don't add much to the grade.
content.location: In the "Back Nine" area, on the "Monster" boulder, adjacent to "Cyclops".

content.description: Start low in the middle of the face, just left of a tree.  Make a move up to incut holds, then move right, behind the tree and around the corner.
content.location: In the "Back Nine" area, on the "Monster" boulder, which is at the very end of the boulder field, adjacent to the "Cyclops" boulder.

content.description: Not the purdiest rock, but the movement is fantastic!  Start below a few "obvious" finger pockets, and tech your way up to them.  Rock over to the left onto the slab, and topout on easier terrain.  Go straight back and hike around to the left to get off.
content.location: In the back nine, follow the main trail past the Graham Cracker boulder, past Deception, Past White trash into a long, shady/mossy corridor.  This problem is on the East facing wall on the left side of the corridor, and it may not be obvious at first. Look for a slabby rock with pockets halfway up.

content.description: Start on a good ledge for the right hand and a poor lefthand undercling.  Move up the face and over the roof on pockets and juggy things.
content.protection: A few pads as it could be possible to fall into the hole to the left or hit the block behind.
content.location: In the upper area by "Pure Rock Fury" and 15' right of "The Eyes Have It."  Look for a sweeping clean wall capped by an interesting roof.

content.description: **Only climbable during the Triple Crown Competition** Start on chest high sidepull dishes, then make easy moves right before getting high feet and finishing up the runnel on bad slopers
content.location: On the golf course, far right side of Cloud Nine Boulder

content.description:
Midway is a strong candidate for the most uninteresting problem in the entire boulderfield. Seriously, it's a completely horizontal, 3' high crack traverse! But what it lacks in charm, it makes up for in fun, extremely physical movement. Consider this a litmus test for finger strength/campus ability. 

  The starting hold is quite obvious, as it is the biggest hold under the roof (Note: A V12 extension called the Chattanoogan starts about 7' to the left and finishes on Midway). Start matched on this heavily chalked, left-facing sidepull, making use of the only discernible foot hold on the route- it looks good enough until you realize just how slick it is. Follow the seam rightward, gunning for the end of the roof. Expect to encounter small, shallow incuts for the next few feet as you precisely stab your way to increasingly better holds. Follow jugs until you're clear of the roof, and rock over onto a sizable foot ledge...and that's it!
content.protection: Pad, but it's completely safe without one...very lowball
content.location: Underneath the Chattanoogan roof, just across from Shotgun and Elephant Riders. Just look for the obvious, low roof.

content.description: Climb up middle of short face with shallow pockets and sidepulls.
content.location: The middle of a short detached block in a corner on the back wall behind and left of the Bowling Ball boulder. On the Cornerstone boulder

content.description: Start the same as for Mescal but climb straight up instead of angling left.
content.location: On the back side of the Dos Cosanos boulder (the boulder opposite the Project wall) - third line from the right.

content.description: Climbs left to right and up on the overhanging side of the boulder on rounded incut holds.
content.location: In the Entrance area on the Dos Cosanos boulder, near the Project wall.  See photo.

content.description: Start as for The Big Much V4 on the left. Move up a couple moves then traverse to the right at mid height. Finish as for Jerry's Kids V7. Burly start, then crimpy.
content.location: Jerry's Kids Boulder, Jungle Gym Area. Not far from Castaway. Towards the back wall (but not quite there) in the middle area, the next area after the first area with The Bowling Ball Boulder and such.

content.description: A slopey traverse with a hard topout!Sit start on a nice set of jugs. Pull on and move left across a nice sloping crescent feature. The holds get worse further left, once at the end of the rail, make a big move to another sloping rail, and continue left along another series of rails and topout  with difficulty.This problem starts to the right of "Fish Market" on obvious jugs. It climbs through the rail of the mentioned problem and continues left staying low and topping out as for "Barnacle Boy".
content.protection: 2 pads. Topout is cruxy, the rest is lowball enough that a slider or blubber should suffice.
content.location: This problem is found just behind the classic "Jerry's Kids" on the lowball overhang with the obvious sloping crescent rail and stays low climbing all the way left and topping out just before or at the arete.

content.description: From the Wellman guidebook: About halfway through this problem you will understand where the name comes from. Start on the rail to the right of the beginning of The Wave. The Mechanic moves out the very steep roof and finishes up the slab as smooth as the hood of a car.
content.location: On the Wave boulder. Begins just right of The Wave.

content.description: Start on the underclings and reach high up to the runnel holding the barn door as you go.
content.location: inbetween ghengis and the wave.

content.description: Great rock with some awkward moves and difficult footwork.  Sit start low near the right end of the face on the juggy flake, move left towards the tree to top out on the slabby groov in the center of the face.
content.location: On the N Face of the Slice and Dice boulder in the Entrance Area.

content.description: Start low on the arete on the right. Make a couple moves up to the horizontal seam then traverse left on the crimpy seam, topping out on Skeleton Crew. Harder the larger your fingers are.
content.location: Opposite side of the boulder from Bonesaw V5. Located downhill of the Sternum area.

content.description: Start as for Trailer Hitch but traverse right thru the break until you can pull the low lip. Very defined crux section at the end.
content.location: Trailer Hitch in the Dragon lady/ Tristar area.

content.description: Climbs cool rounded jugs up an uninspiring face.
content.location: In the Entrance Area, on the Crescent Boulder. Around the corner, to the right of the Crescent Crack.

content.description: Stand start inside the crevasse using the jugs and climb up and to the right on good holds. (your back will almost be touching the boulder behind you) Find the big undercling pocket and make your way out of the roof section to huge jugs and top out.
content.protection: Gonna need a few pads inside the crevasse to protect your head and back if you fall.
content.location: Jerry's Kids Boulder, Jungle Gym Area

content.description: Climb the easy slab up cool edges on the left side of the face
content.location: Located in the front area on the Crescent Boulder.  Just left of black water stain.

content.description: A leftward traverse in the low obvious seam. Start on the right side of the boulder. traverse left and make casual moves on good holds until you have to campus it out to the big shelf. topout.
content.location: The boulder behind the jerrys kids boulder.

content.description: Start sitting as for "Keel Hauled".  Traverse left on a good rail until the going gets tough.  Pick your poison from a couple of tiny sharp crimpers, get situated and make a big move to the starting holds of "Brians Brain".  Finish up on this climb.
content.location: The lage sunny face in the Main Area, right of the Dragon Lady corridor.  Start matched on the "Keel Hauled" starting holds.

content.description:
A pretty little arete problem with "bread loaf" features and a challenging sloper topout. 

  Sit start on a good sidepull just left of the arete. Squeeze between edges on the arete and edges on the steep face.  Set up on a good undercling, make a big move to a disappointing sloper and haul yourself over the lip.
content.protection: At least one pad.  Very safe landing.
content.location: On the backside of the Chronic Boulder.  Facing the golf course.

content.description: Climb left arete of block. Stand start, climb to top on good holds.
content.location: The left arete of a short detached block in a corner on the back wall behind and left of the Bowling Ball boulder. On the Cornerstone boulder

content.description: A proud 70 degree overhang starting on a decent incut crimp for both hands. Get a foot out in front of you and pull on with some serious body tension. Core up and pull in tight, getting the left hand as close to your shoulder as possible and reach as far as you can to the slopey hold on the roof. From here come in to an incut hold near your right hand. Pull off another hard lock-off to a decent hold at the lip, keep it together and reach up to a choice of holds before reaching up right hand to a mono. Figure out how to snag the lip before topping out on good holds.
content.location: Some-what hidden, this problem is easily missed. It is located in a corridor in the middle area.

content.description: crimp your way up and step off up and right.
content.location: through the hole around the corner of tristar

content.description:
Stand start the slab with a sloping horizontal iron-band. Find enough friction to pull onto the slab with a bad foot and smack up to a bad melon sloper. Somehow match and smack again to the large sloping ramp. Stand on the ramp then walk off.

The starting nubbins are really bad, like barely holds bad.
content.location: Found on the same boulder as "Odyssey" and "Watermelon Slab".From the lot, hike down the steps past the first large cluster of boulders, and this cluster is up and left. Follow the trails. "Space" and "Odyssey" are two similar looking slopey slabby aretes that stand out. There is a wooden cabin on too of the two blocks bridging them together.Just to the right of "Watermelon Slab", which is to the right of the big sloping arete "Odyssey".

content.description: The low to Kneed It. Start spanned with right hand on low flat edge and left hand on a sloper with a divot. Make a hard move up to the bottom of the left-facing feature. Work up the feature to top out on slopers. The problem name provides some beta. Extra beta: have someone toss up a Kevlar suit for the bramble schwack. This is a good one to climb once you’ve exhausted all other nearby options as your buddy works The Shield.
content.protection: Three pads are nice. It’s also good to have someone spotting up on the block climber’s left.
content.location: On the Shiver Me Timbers boulder. Left of Devil’s Cabana Boy on the adjacent face.

content.description: Start with right hand on arete crystal and left hand on a sidepull. Work up the left-facing feature and top out on slopers. The problem name provides some beta. Extra beta: have someone toss up a Kevlar suit for the bramble schwack. This is a good one to climb once you’ve exhausted all other nearby options as your buddy works The Shield.
content.protection: Three pads are nice. It’s also good to have someone spotting up on the block climber’s left.
content.location: On the Shiver Me Timbers boulder. Left of Devil’s Cabana Boy on the adjacent face.

content.description: Stand start with right hand side-pull.  Trust your feet and slap your way up slopers to mantle finish.
content.location: Backside of The Bowling Ball boulder in the Front Area.

content.description: One of Stone Fort's hardest and proudest V10's. Stand start on the left arête with hands matched in the thin crack as for the V5. Move up and right to the blocky gaston and make an insecure match before moving up to the chalky sidepull under the bulge. Hand heel match and figure out a way to get to the good edge out right before releasing the heel and taking a heroic swing high of the deck. A right heel hook and a couple lock offs get you standing on top of the ledge where you can walk off out right.
content.location: On the Tristar Boulder left of Celestial Mechanics

content.description: Low crux, aim for the crescent shaped dish. May be toproped if you're into that kind of thing.
content.location: Approximately 5 feet left of "Storming the Castle" on the Castle Wall in the Front Line Area.

content.protection: A few pads and a spotter.
content.location: From the main area with "Spanky", "Celestial Mechanics"  and "King James". This problem is on the front face of the boulder on the golf course.

content.description: Start at the bottom of the arete in pockets and climb up to the top of the arete.
content.location: Just uphill from Conway Twittt Twister (on its left side), there is a long low angle arete on a boulder that looks like a triangle.

content.description: Begin a sit start, same as Deciduous Enema(V4) but climb up and left to finish along a vertical crack. Great holds and an overhanging start provide a good pump leading to a slopey topout.
content.protection: Tall sketchy top out. Good spotter advised.
content.location: Area 51, The Frontside. There is a tree growing into the rock.

content.description: Start on opposing vertical incuts, move up and slightly right on good holds to scoop feature. Continue up and right via side pull and dimple to thin crimp/ear. Find some feet and move up to good holds at the top.
content.location: In the front. Tall face to the right of Spyro Gyro. Right of small tree below big scoop feature.

content.description: Great route, a must do when you get to it
Stand start in jug shelf. Make a couple of fun moves through a pocket and a sharp sidepull jug.
content.protection: A pad on top of the boulder behind the problem is helpful.
content.location: This is the leftmost chalked line on the Frumundathunda boulder (but not the groove/crack that The Curse ends on).

content.description: Stand start on the flake at head level and head up the slab using pockets and pinches.
content.location: On the left side of the Humpty Dumpty slab in the front area. Look for the flake at about head level and the start is on the right side of the flake.

content.description:
Sit start low as for "White Trash", matched on a heavily chalked horizontal jug.  Move left and up a right-facing dihedral feature to iron crimps on the slab above.  Make a reach to a pair of pockets and continue up the slab.  

  This is a great problem with lots of climb requiring a diversity of skills.
content.protection: This is fairly tall and a fall from the top is possible, so bring many pads and a good spotter.
content.location: In "The Back Nine", just past Deception, locate a tall, long west facing wall with several problems. This is the second problem from the right, just left of "White Trash".

content.description: Start with your feet tucked into a tiny cave, a decent sloper/edge for your left hand and a slopey pinch for the right. Hard moves off the ground will get you to decent sloping edges and slopers below the crux. Choose your beta adventure using the edges or an undercling to gain a good edge waaaay up and right (there's an intermediate available too). Top out straight up using a flat jug and good feet.
content.protection: A couple pads and a spotter or two.
content.location: On the tall face of the Jerry's Kids boulder in the Jungle Gym area.

content.description: Sit start with a left hand pocket and a wide pocket thumb catch. Right hand is on an adjacent pocket pinch.Pull on with some scrunchy feet and smack out left to a good pocket sidepull. Some hard foot moves lead to a tension match on the large pocket. Once matched on the pocket, figure out a way to reach left to a sloping sidepull pocket and continue up with a hard move to the horizontal and a fun topout that feels a bit exposed due to lack of holds.This sit start adds two hard hand moves and several foot moves into "Jam Up", making it more full value and more likely to be the proposed grade of V8.The problem climbed well and I thought others might enjoy it also.
content.location: This problem is found in the middle of the pocketed vert wall. It is the boulder to the right of "Odyssey" and "Watermelon Slab". Same boulder as "Two Shoes Jack".

content.description: lay-down start to delicate sloper traverse to finishing as Jerry's Kids. Start with left hand on crimp flake and right hand on second crimp just above the first one. Traverse left to the start of Jerry's Kids.
content.location: Starts just 5 feet right of Jerry's Kids in the area behind the climb Castaway in the front-middle of Stone Fort just before Ribcage and Sternum.

content.description: Start on obvious pockets and shoot for a pocket/sidepull below a big break in the boulder. Get to the break and topout directly above.
content.protection: a pad, watch for the tree
content.location: Located to the left of Slow Poke on the Two Shoes Jack boulder. Look for obvious pockets and a topout where the moss has been worn away.

content.description: Classic one move wonder. Start on crimps with bad feet and make a wild move up and across your body to a downward sloping horn with your right hand. Keep the barn door from spitting you off and you have it in the bag. Climb up ~10 more feet on good edges and traverse right to dismount. Watch out for dirty holds up there.
content.protection: Pads. Helpful to bring a chalkbag and brush up for the top.
content.location: Back Nine Area

content.description: A logical extension to "Instinct", and arguably the more natural problem.  Start in the very back of the cave on a foot-wide 1-pad crimp. The wall behind you is off, and it will take some effort to avoid it.  Bust right along the rail on poor crimps with worse feet.  Join Instinct and finish on that.
content.location: In the "Back Nine" area, walk right around the Graham Crackers boulder, then continue straight along a faint path between boulders (don't go into the Biggie Shorty corridor), about 50 feet past Graham Crackers, Instinct will appear on the left in a tight corner.

content.description: A classic problem that starts high and finishes higher with big, insecure moves.  The rock is a bit lower quality than most Stone Fort problems, and this can sometimes be wet. Nevertheless, the movement is great, and an ascent is always exciting. Start halfway out the chalked rail on a big left hand flake and your right on a slopey crimp.  Make a big move out right to an incut spike, then up to the lip.  After pulling the lip, move left into the chimney and head back into the Biggie Shorty corridor to get down.
content.location: In the "Back Nine" area, walk right around the Graham Crackers boulder, then continue straight along a faint path between boulders (don't go into the Biggie Shorty corridor), about 50 feet past Graham Crackers, Instinct will appear on the left in a tight corner.

content.description: Ok, so it sounds like it's not going to be that great, but it really is!    This is kind of the second variation of the Incredarete (stand, sit, and left sit). It starts seated on perfect rounded crimps on the left face around the corner, with a right toe hook on the arete. Work feet, and do really great feeling moves up through the left facing side pull at about 6 feet. Use that to get yourself back over to the Incredarete, and finish on that.    This is a surprisingly fun v4, and I think more fun than stand and center sit starts. Worth doing.
content.location: Start on left side of Incredarete on crimps, work up and then right, and finish on Incredarete.

content.description: Sit start to IncredArete.  Climb the arete via slopers to jugs and a nice, high top out.
content.location: Mystery Machine boulder...you can't miss the arete.

content.description: Climb slopers on arete to jugs and a high finish
content.location: Mystery Machine boulder

content.description: SDS as for Genghis Khan traverse left to a good sidepull and small feet.  Make a huge move to the lip.
content.location: Wave Boulder

content.description: Besides the perfect rock, this is not a particularly interesting problem. Just grit your teeth and pull on tiny, painful crimps. Cold weather, deadpoint accuracy, and good footwork help.
content.protection: Funky landing, so bring pads and spotters.
content.location: In the Entrance area on the South face of the  "Mystery Machine" boulder.

content.description:
Bring a rope to LRC? You must be kidding!  Unless you like a little hard wide roof crack. 

  I think the most accurate rating is 5.11d+++ but maybe that's just because it is such a unique and sequential climb.  Hard to rate. A sick offwidth roof that climbs real nice...

 If it hasn't seen action in a while, bring brushes, goggles and possibly a leafblower.  Lots of stuff accumulates in the crack over time.
content.protection: Standard rack would do, you can go all "Seperate Reality" style to protect the initial chimney.  I used up to a #6.  Drop me a PM if you "need" even more beta.
content.location: Wander to almost Area 51...walk by Glamour Boy and Girl boulder.  A sick roof crack on the cliffband will either be a lodestone or utterly repulse you.  This is the Human Chew Toy.

content.description: This is a super classic problem with great moves and an exciting finish.  Stand start in the right hueco, then move up the face with long, powerful moves.
content.protection: The landing is sloping, but flat, so a few pads and a good spotter are a must.  The topout holds can accumulate dust and debris, so you might want to scramble to the top to clean these off before casting off.
content.location: About halfway through the boulderfield, just past the "Main Area" is the Cinderella boulder.  This is located on the back side of this boulder, and can be reached by tunnelling through just right of "Cleopatra", or walking around the formation by going up to Super Mario then doubling back towards the Cinderella boulder.  It is on a greenish wall right where the boulder joins the next boulder, look for some conspicuous huecos.

content.description: Climb Red House Extension, but don't rock over to the right of the boulder. Instead, utilize a pinch to make a long standup move, and then get a great heel hook that feels much less secure than it actually is. Rock up to a sidepull and make a committing move out left to an incut rail, and finish up the easy topout. This is the same grade as Red House Extension, but adds quite a few more V4-ish moves, and topping out can be scary. A very proud line, and one of the most classic at Stone Fort!
content.protection: Lots of pads, including on the boulder to left of the main boulder, as there is fall potential here.  Make sure you have spotters, too!
content.location: On the Super Mario boulder

content.description: Sit start on the lowest chalked holds and climb straight up to top out. Alternatively, start on a crimp rail on the arete and traverse in on slopers to the same top out. Both are low cruxes with an easy top out.
content.protection: A pad if going direct, two if traversing.
content.location: On the main trail side of the Slice and Dice boulder. The first route on the boulder, just left of the tree.

content.description: A few hard moves on bad holds lead to better slopey holds at the lip. Sit start on two thin crimps and pull onto the wall. Move up to a sidepull and a gaston with difficulty before hitting the lip.
content.location: On the main trail on the boulder before "Pancake Mantle" and "Steam Roller".

content.description: The start is on the crimps to the right of the Slow and Low start (which starts in the hueco). The top out is up and slightly to the right and finishes on some nice slopers. Traverse right to downclimb or hop down from the top.
content.location: In the Fish Lips boulders. The right-most route on the short overhanging face that contains Pure Rock Fury and Slow and Low.

content.description: Sit start on sloper crimps down and right of the crack. Move left towards the arete using the side pull jug rail. Head straight up the right side of the arete to a tricky top out.
content.protection: A couple of pads and a spotter
content.location: Follow approach directions to Now and Zen or Dr. Atkinson. This is the arete to the right of Now and Zen, and it starts on the right side of the arete on the bottom right side of the crack there.

content.description: Climb the tall face via slopers to a few good holds at the top.
content.location: The Crescent Boulder.  A few feet to the left of The Crescent.

content.description: start on jugs/arete, go up and left onto a technical slab with a left-foot standup to the slopy top.
content.location: moss man area

content.description: Climb a nice, but somewhat sharp, finger and hand crack. When the crack peters out, traverse left and down-climb the easy slab to the East.
content.location: In the old Main Area, on the Philip's Fury boulder (directly East of the Tristar boulder). This is the splitter crack on the left side of the tall North face of the boulder.

content.description:
You could call this one a one move wonder. 

  Sit start matched on an obvious crimp rail about three and a half feet off the ground. Choose from a few foot options before pulling on and launching about five or six feet to the jug lip of the boulder. Once here match hands and top out.
content.protection: 2 or 3 pads. The landing is quite good, but the potential for dry firing off the start hold is quite high due to the amount of force needed to do the move.
content.location: About ten feet to the right of "Castaway"

content.description: Grab the biggest jug at LRC, move up to a crimp and an undercling.  Explode up to a sloping dish/bucket and hold the barndoor.  Finish on the slab above.
content.protection: Pads would be a good idea.
content.location: Left of "Junkie" and "White Trash" in the back nine area.  The first boulder after passing "Deception."

content.description: Get ready for some serious lactic acid build up as you link Swingers into Smoking Jacket! There's some seriously classic and gymnastic movement on this 20+ move problem. Surf the slopers of Swingers to the incut rail, heels over yer head, latch out right and hold a BIG OL swing into the lil edge of Smoking Jacket. Cross over or bump into sloper heaven and make the last few redpoint crux moves to the top of Smoking Jacket. Pizza de resistance.
content.location: Swingers Boulder

content.description: Stand start on a horn and continue up
content.location: Dumb luck boulder

content.description: Climb up a bulging, sloping slab via the aforementioned underclings.
content.location: The Crescent Boulder.  A few feet right of The Crescent

content.description: Start on pockety edge.  Stand up to slopers and mantle
content.location: In the Entrance Area, on the "Bowling Ball" boulder, adjacent to the Firecrack boulder.

content.description: Sit start to Mother Trutch, the V4. Sit on a slopey crimp and move straight up into the roof. Finish up the crimps and make it to the jugs.
content.location: After you pass the corridor with tristar, keep walking on the trail and it will be on your left. The wall before the pancake mantle wall

content.description: Quality, conditions-dependent sloper climbing.
content.location: In the alcove behind Crack of Doom, directly facing Face in the Crowd.

content.description: Start at the heuco to the left of the Wave.  Delicately slab your way to the top via smears and the arete edge.
content.location: Wave Boulder.  The slab to the left.  Look for big heuco

content.description: A super classic, tall arete on one of the coolest boulders in the universe. I've seen this graded harder, but it's so easy to use big jugs just to the right.  IMO, the moves are more interesting, and it's slightly harder to stick to smaller holds near the edge. If so, climb straight up the arete, occasionally using crimps on the right side with balancey, barndoor moves.
content.location: In the "Back Nine" area, this is the tall arete on the "Graham Crackers" boulder, which you pass right before heading up the slab towards "Deception".

content.description: A cool problem that would be more classic in a better location. Sit start on a large tree route between two boulders. Use a slopey pocket for left and a sloper jug for right, sort of compressing. Move up and left, follow the sloping rail, and top out at the highest point of the boulder. May need a little brushing but mostly good to go.
content.location: In the Pit. Behind Art of the Vogi is a pit. its in here. If you're at Swingers, turn around and face Vogi, and you will walk into it.

content.description: Sit start under the short roof matched on a decent rail. Pull on and move up to slopers at the lip of the boulder and traverse out left. Reach up to a good hold and topout on more slopers.
