content.location: Located in the "Moss Man Area", on s rather short boulder, this problem lies on the right side of the face and shares the same top out as for "The Barrier".

content.description:
Sit-start on the jug horizontal just left of the large tree. Pull on and move up to a grainy finger-lock and execute a hard lock-off to a sloping pinch in the groove, from here continue direct up the black water groove. Powerful, and one sharp hold leads to skin friendly polished rock up and neat groove created by thousands of years of erosion.

 The top of this problem sometimes catches leaves and debris which cause it to seep. I recently cleaned several years of dirt leaves and a bit of vegetation off of the top of the groove and cleaned it up in order to get it into climbable condition. This problem rarely sees attention, possibly from the painful, but good finger-lock guarding the groove.
content.location: This problem is located about 5 or 6 feet to the right of the large slopey arête used for "Bear Hug Arête".

content.description: Sweet problem, that doesn't give up the whole way till you top out, a must do!

Start as for Genghis Khan, but make a long reach or dyno right to a slopey groove and top out...probably the more direct line.  

  RC.com lists this as V7, but 6 seems better to me.
content.location: Entrance area, on the Wave boulder, this is the arete between the Wave and the golf course

content.description: Sit start under the steep overhand with a rounded right hand sidepull and left-hand on the sloping arete. Figure out the feet, and smack up the arete and fire out to a shallow hueco-like dish for the right. Continue smacking up the arete and make a blind move to a jug. Execute the mantle then venture up the highball topout, or call it quits and drop off.The topout slab is adventurous. I cleaned most of the holds I used. The downclimb was an adventure as well.
content.location: This problem is located in the back of the boulderfield on the same steep overhang as "Rust". It climbs the left sloping arete compressing holds on the overhang.Venture into the Back Nine past "Shiver Me Timbers" and "The Shield". Past "Instinct", and this steep overhang is found on the right. It is surrounded by brambles.

content.description: Totally sweet problem, start under a roof and fall back and climb over the roof on sloping holds.  set up for the dyno on a sloping pinch and a sloping crimp and just throw with all you've got for the huge jug, next its just one more big reach to a good hold up high and left, then topout.
content.protection: Pad and a spotter. Watch the rock behind you.
content.location: Just up the hill past the first main bouldering area. "The Forbidden City".

content.description:
Start on Rage, and boldly fire straight out the roof through some pockets rather than doing the awkward knee bar thing on the left. Finish by working up sloper jugs to the left until you are at the apex.  

  Cool tension, a big throw, and nice little sloper jugs at the end make this one a much better climb than Rage, I believe.
content.location: Butt-side of the Super Mario boulder. Start on Rage, and go straight out the roof.

content.description: The left line of the pod lines
content.location: Funhouse boulder

content.description: Starts on right side of Fromundathunda Boulder just left of the cave, SDS on jugs moving up to obvious slopers, then trending right on better holds to an easy finish.
content.location: Fromundathunda Boulder

content.description: Dope fridgey climb at a low grade. Start at obvious grips and slap up.
content.location: Fairway boulders. Only climbable during the Triple Crown competition.

content.description: A short boulder with an interesting move. The first move. I like it but nobody else did. A giant move to a super sharp hold brings you up to some junky holds.
content.location: Start with the left on a nice crimp and your right hand on the a side pull crimp around the corner of the arete.

content.description: Starts on a low crack/arete feature that is often seeping.  Goes straight up to a few little pockets: big one on the left, mono on the right, and a HIGH right foot.  The crux comes down to a full-on right leglift on the little edge.  Basically, it's a one-move v6 foot move!
content.location: as you walk behind the Deception boulder and pass White Trash, you will see a left path go back and into a little cove just before you trend toward the Cyclops area.  This cove contains the fun twin v6's, Fame and Fortune.  Fortune is the rightmost problem, which ends on an obvious slab.

content.description: Blunt arete with bulbous sidepulls and slopers
content.location: Slice and Dice Boulder opposite Main Event

content.description: Squat start with left hand in the pocket and right hand on the pinch. Up and out left of arete.
content.location: Backside of Dragon Lady area. Walk to the far left of Dragon Lady past smog through the downclimb corridor of Dragon Lady. There is a short obvious arete just straight ahead.

content.description: A beautiful and pure line on brick-hard holds. Stand start matched on a somewhat slopey crimp-rail about 8.5-9 feet off the ground. (Stack pads if you can't reach, or jump start it and give it the v12) Pull on to the wall with difficulty and choose your foot placement. Unleash your inner Doctor J. and dunk the flat edge about 5 feet above the starting hold. Match hands then trend rightward onto a large shelf before down climbing or dropping off.
content.protection: 5 or 6 pads. 3 is minimum. It is a high start and you are jumping with everything you have. The landing is uneven and a rock slab is a few feet behind you, which causes the pads to slide when you land.
content.location: From  "Tennessee Thong"  look left to a corridor with a tree at its entrance. There are two V11 dyno problems in this corridor. This is the right most and is about a 5 foot jump move.

content.description: *ONLY CLIMBABLE DURING THE STONE FORT TRIPLE CROWN COMPETITION** Climb the sloping water groove using laybacks and smears.
content.location: A few feet left of El Camino

content.description: Start on right hand crimp/sidepull.  Stand on bad feet.  Crimp to the top out.
content.location: Crescent Boulder - back side.

content.description: A great v0 on clean, solid rock. Head over there to get away from the masses warming up in the rest of the Front.
content.location: Right side of the face on the Mystery Groove boulder that is directly across from Storming the Castle, v1.

content.description: Jaunty v0 action on the taller side of the Fish Market boulder. Sit start and work straight up through big holds to a cruiser topout. No. 95 of the impossibly good v0s that LRC holds.
content.location: Tallest face of the Fish Market boulder, around the corner to the right when facing the Fish Market, Big Wheel, Soapmakers.

content.description: Sit-start. Climb the short, steep face. Engineer moves to conquer the brain like topout.
content.protection: A pad or two with an attentive spotter.
content.location: The Fish Market Boulder in The Jungle Gym Area.

content.description:
Traverse the series of conglomerated jugs left to right. Follow the directionals up. 

   *Remember that its a traverse so its 19 feet long, but only about 10 feet high* 

  I left a but of blood on the ce flash. It may still be there...
content.protection: Have a spotter dragging a pad.
content.location: The Fish Market Boulder in the Jungle Gym Area.

content.description: One move wonder. Start with hands in two shallow scoops and make big move to the big obvious jug halfway up the arete, and rock over to top out.
content.location: In the Fish Lips Boulders area. Around the backside of the boulders on the lefthand side is a small corridor. The climb is in that corridor on the left side on a roundy arete.

content.description: Climbs a large, detached flake on the corner of the Fire Crack boulder. Although geologic change is often measured in thousands to millions of years, it can also be measured in seconds. The fact that this flake has thus far withstood the weight of untold dangling hominids is no testament to its future competence.
content.location: On the Fire Crack boulder in the Front Area.

content.description: Just left of High Tide. Start on underlings and climb the techy slab direct.

A bit of a highball. Begin on the far right side of the boulder on jugs. Move up and slightly left to a break about 8 feet up. A dyno gets you to a decent sloper. From there it's all about keeping it together to top it out.
content.protection: A few pads and a spotter are definitely recommended. Not a great fall if you blow the dyno.
content.location: Far right line on the tall boulder just to the left of Jerry's Kids.

content.description: The Feature is the obvious crack on the back side of Crescent. Stand start and pull into the crack. No real jams to be had. Mantle the top out.
content.location: The backside of the Crescent boulder.

content.description: SDS as for Chronic on the rippled sloper, moving up and right to a crimp and next sloper, but continue right around the corner on low percentage holds to the slab. Top out direct.
content.location: Sternum area - Chronic Boulder

content.description:
A tall arete with a tricky start, fun edging in the middle and an airy transition around the arete up top. 

  Stand start with your right hand in an obvious pocket and your left hand around the arete palming the wall.   Perch on a left heel, and make a subtle move to a sidepull.   Follow edges up the right side of the arete, move left around the arete and keep moving left until you can mantle.   

  Escape right under the roof. 

  If this has already been climbed I will happily change the name and ascent info.
content.protection: At least two pads.  This route has a two tiered landing zone and a tree that you need to avoid if you fall.
content.location: The arete just left of Interplanetary Escape.

content.description: Climb a series of pockets, sidepulls, and slopers just to the left of the arete problem Thundafrumunda.

A nice warmup that climbs left to right across the N face of the Slice and Dice boulder.  Start on jugs at the left end of the horizontal crack, traverse right, squeezing behind the tree to finish on slopey jugs.
content.location: On the N face of the "Slice and Dice" boulder in the Entrance Area.

content.description: The left-hand arete of Funhouse Boulder. The guidebook calls this problem the "coolest line on the boulder." Squat start on large jug on arete and climb up the arete to jugs at the top.
content.location: On the far left of Funhouse Boulder. In the Jungle Gym Area, the closest boulder to Castaway Boulder.

content.description: Slabby climbing with a high start in a horizontal, up to a flake out left, and ends on a traverse out a horizontal crack to the right.
content.location: as you walk behind the Deception boulder and pass White Trash, you will see a left path go back and into a little cove just before you trend toward the Cyclops area.  This cove contains the fun twin v6's, Fame and Fortune.

content.description: Begin to the right of "Split" and just to the left of "Gutter Ball". Using a running start, propel yourself off the bottom of the boulder, reach for the slopers, and top out.
content.location: Bowling Ball Area

content.description: Stand on a low ledge and match on a vertical rail to walk up left to a nice ledge for your left foot. Get right foot far out right onto a nice, triangular foothold and right hand into the eye of the cyclops smiley. Get a left hand up high, using the edge of the crack to balance while grabbing a good edge to the right with your right hand. A little higher up the crack is a good hold which you can use to get onto a nice rail, traverse left using the crack halfway up the problem for feet. Let me know if this has had an ascent before and I will change the FA!
content.location: Behind the Cuervo boulder. Wall to the right of the ravine system (Castle Wall). Look for a noticeable "cyclops" smiling.

content.description: On the mystery machine boulder, around to the left of incredarete. Use the obvious chalked rail and go straight up, toping out to the left of incredarete. Its the same sit start for Incredarete left sit, but it does not use the arete.
content.location: Mystery machine boulder

content.description: Cool alligator skin arete.  Start on two sidepulls and figure your way to the top on sloping pockets and more sidepulls.  Enjoy the brainy slopey topout.
content.location: Just to the right on Shotgun on the arete.

content.description: Rightmost problem with Swingers Boulder to left and Project Wall behind it. Sit start and pull roof to jugs. Walk Off.
content.location: Dos Cosanos Boulder in the front area.

content.description: **ONLY CLIMABLE DURING STONE FORT COMP!  Start on a awkward undercling to the L of the arete and pull through a couple pockets to move out Left and gain the slopey runnel.  Layback the runnel to gain the high slopey pinch just below the nice slopers for th etopout.
content.protection: Pad and spot, a bit high.
content.location: Located on the 18th Hole on the El Camino Boulder in the alcove formed between this boulder and the Big Mike Boulder

content.description: Climb the low angle face. This is the easiest downclimb for the Mystery Machine boulder.
content.location: On the far right side of the backside of the Mystery Machine boulder.

content.description: Stand start on the arete of "Country Redneck Bitch" and climb up and left into the slopey crack feature and traverse left through "Deception" and finish up the left arete as for "Open It Up".
content.location: To the right of "Deception".

content.description: and honestly a dumb problem. Start very, very low on a big chalked flake and use the arete to move up. There is a huge tree right in the spot you want it to not be. That being said, get creative. The crux is probably the first two moves as you negotiate the scrunchiness.
content.location: When walking up to Super Mario, the problem will be on your left just as you turn left to go up to the SM boulder. Its right across from Spank the Baby. Right on the trail.

content.description: This mild-looking problem has some cool holds down low, but packs a punch with powerful underclings up high followed by a tall but easy topout.
content.location: Next to Destroyer, down the hill towards the fairway from Super Mario in a cluster of tall boulders. This is to the right of Destroyer on the next boulder over and starts on cool chickenhead jugs.

content.description: Do the Dragon Traverse (left to right under the first roof on jugs - V0), then climb up to the second roof and traverse back on slightly smaller holds.  As a matter of courtesy, consider not smearing your feet all over the critical holds for the V9 and V11 problems that you will be traversing through.  This will unnecessarily polish and wear down these holds.
content.location: On the South face of the Dragon Lady boulder in the old Main Area.

content.description: Traverse, left to right, the juggy crack under the first roof of the Dragon Lady boulder.  A nice warmup.
content.location: On the South face of the Dragon Lady boulder in the old "Main Area".

content.description: Shares a start with Dragon Slayer on pockets in the roof's seam. Use holds under the roof to get a right hand on the crimp/left-facing sidepull shared with Dragon slayer. Move left to a crimp under the roof, get a high left foot, and lock off to pockets below the next tier. Traverse left on jugs, or top out.
content.location: On the Dragon Boulder in the Main Area. Dragon Man is the boulder's center line, between Dragon Lady and Dragon Slayer.

content.description: Classic line!!  Make a long move to gain the lip, and wrestle to the jugs above and climb to the top,
content.location: At the end of the alley way where the mega classic Celestial Mechanics (v7) is located.

content.protection: A pad. A spotter isn't a bad idea either.
content.location: Located near Dragon Lady, Tristar and Celestial Mechanics; in what is referred to as the Main Area in the Stonefort guidebook.

content.description: Sit start on a big undercling, then move up through some pockets into a positive top-out.
content.location: Located on the right side of the Your Sister's Boulder.

content.description: Technique and the ability to do some strong underclinging on sharp crimps will serve you well on this fantastic climb.   Start sitting on the pocket-type holds, stand up and power into the sharp undercling crimps. Hold the tension and grab a super cool right hand grip, and then do probably the funnest move ever (there may be a wicked drop knee involved (maybe)). This is the meat of it, and the rest of it is not so bad with good beta.   I did not climb at LRC enough to know if this is typical for the area, but I thought it was just great.
content.location: Woah. Hard to find for sure. It's next to Now and Zen. These problems are in an upper corridor that is accessed by walking uphill from the Jungle Gym boulder and Fish Lips, then left towards the club house. Once above the level of most of the boulders, walk towards clubhouse and a fenced off area. Before you get to the fenced off area, you can look down to the left, and see a little gully corridor. Once down there, Now and Zen and Dr. Atkinson will be on a wall to the right. Now and Zen is the steeper of the two, and Dr. Atkinson is to the left.

content.description: A full value v1 with tough footwork at the start that leads to big moves and a committing topout (for the grade) at 15 feet. Great stuff.
content.location: On the arete just right of the perfect Galaxy 5000, v5.

content.description: More Fantastic climbing! Begin to the far left and climb off to exit at twin cracks.
content.protection: A GOOD spotter and a leashed down pad.
content.location:
Graham Cracked Boulder, The Back Nine 

  Walk right from the start until you see a giant heuco, climb down from it on this v0---

content.description: Another seam traverse. Start on the right as for Finish Your Homework and move left, staying in the lower of the two seams. Traverse around the corner and drop off.
content.location: on the wall left of jerrys kids

content.description: Stand start with the left hand on a sharp incut crimp and the right hand on a similar style and sized crimp just to the right. Pick some feet and pull onto the wall. Make a hard long move up to another sharp crimp right hand, before reaching up lefty and topping out in slopey featured terrain.
content.location: This boulder problem is located on the steep overhang right behind "Diesal Power". From "Fat Cat", walk left to the steep orange colored overhang.

content.description: Start the same as Dis, traverse right and finish per the V1 at the end of the block in the crack. Crux is getting around the tree and not dabbing. The way I did it was by jamming feet into the Dis undercligs and crossing into a rounded jug rather far away. Doing it this way resulted in my opinion of V3-, knowing it's markedly harder than Dis, V2.
content.protection: A pad and a spotter to drag it over. Lowball until V1 end.
content.location: Start same as Dis V2 near the Diesel Power bloc where the Thundafrumunda warmups are.

content.description: Hardest of the easy warm-ups in the Thundafromunda area. This line actually has two variations.    The bad one starts sitting under the bulge and works straight up through sloper pinches to a thrutchy Valsalva type maneuver to grab the sloper rail (v2+), and finishes on cool jugs. The good one starts in the same spot, and then rocks hard onto a good left foot so that you can reach a perfectly creamy left sloper side pull (v1). Stand up to big jugs from there. Your choice.
content.location: Left side of the warm up wall on the Robbing the Tooth Fairy/Blind Spot/Diesel Power boulder.

content.description: Fun 5.7 jam crack up a short corner. Good warm up for a LRC crack circuit.
content.location: corridor around the corner of Crack of Doom.

content.description: This problem is considered a classic, with powerful, dynamic moves on big rounded grips. Classic bear-hug moves get you up the steep roof, with a nice topout on rounded jugs.
content.location: This is just past the Entrance area, downhill from "Space" where two large boulders nearly touch.  This is the well chalked roof with a crack at the base. Start with hands in the crack, and climb up the angled roof to the top.

content.description: Fun moves on this short problem.  Start on the right side of the N face, low on the juggy flake.  Move right towards the blunt arete using slopey pinches.
content.location: On the N face of the "Slice and Dice" boulder, in the Entrance Area.

content.description: Follow the crack. Move through a series of big moves to a thought provoking top out.  Wearing pants helps...
content.location: Located on the first boulder, in the back 9.

content.description: A classic tall, overhanging arete with great sculpted holds and good movement.  The landing is terrible, so have good spotters and many pads, or don't fall.
content.location: Near the "Super Mario" boulder, down the hill towards the 18th fairway in a dense cluster of tall boulders.

content.description: Sit-Start and climb the featured arete and commit to the mantle.
content.protection: Lots of pads and spotters. Stack a couple of pads on the sharp stump if needed.
content.location:
How to downclimb: Go down the slab right in front of you is safer and easier. 

  Location: The Front Side, Area 51

content.description: Deception climbs a beautiful gray and orange face through slopey crack features.  Stand start on the left side of the jigsaw wall, left hand on a slopey horizontal and right hand on an incut sidepull.  Execute a precision move to a left hand slot and then continue on with long moves between side pulls.  I recommend 3-4 pads and a good spotter.
content.location: This route is on the jigsaw wall on the back nine.  It is hard to miss since the trail passes right by it.

content.description: "Sit start on the round pink jugs. Climb straight up into an undercling and then follow the flake to the top"
content.location: Daddy loves boulder to the right of Roscoe.

content.description: A great crimpy problem on perfect stone.  Start low on a crimp rail or very low on jugs, move up and left or right on sharp crimps up to the cyclops eye.  The topout isn't hard, but it's insecure, so you'll want several pads and a good spotter.
content.location: In the "Back Nine" area, on the Cyclops boulder, which is essentially the last boulder in the boulder field.  Follow the trail past Deception, White Trash, and Mono Doigt to this boulder.  It is easily identified by the softball-sized "cyclops" eye about 8 feet up in the middle of the wall.

content.description: Start with a left pinch. Climb up pockets to gain good crimps. Mantle the crimps and trust your rubber to top out.
content.location: In the Cell corridor past The Law. The first climb in the corridor. Shares a start with Iron Man Traverse (v7).

content.description: Sit start low on underclings and move up and right on good holds to the top.
content.location: On the back side of the Dos Cosanos boulder (the boulder opposite the Project wall) - second line from the right.

content.description: Climb the slab in between Two Shoe Jack and Clarence Bowater Survival.  Starts with two "nipples" to pinch on.  Smear and slab your way to better holds at the top.
content.location: Space/Odyssey area

content.description: A fun little problem to do if you are in the neighborhood. It's the one that works through the hard-looking (but actually pretty reasonable) rails on the right side of the same face that has Biggie Shorty. Work up through crimps and a good slot jug with a little tension until you do a press down mantle to get onto the slab above. Good stuff. Probably just jump off from there to escape.
content.location: Right side of same face that holds Biggie Shorty

content.description: Start at a jug and climb up the tall face working up the crescent and to the left.
content.location: Crescent Boulder.  Look for the obvious crescent seam.

content.description: Crescent Boulder in the front area, takes the direct line up low percentage holds just left of The Crescent.
content.location: Crescent Boulder, Front Area

content.description: A good long warmup with good rock on an engaging face.  Crimp up the wall on patina edges turning into slopers.  There is a cool ecosystem on the expansive summit of this boulder.
content.location: In the old Main Area, on the Tanqueray boulder (the same boulder Spanky is on). This is on the right side of the tall North face of the boulder, facing the main area towards Brians Bain.

content.description:
Sit start on low jugs, and make a move to a crimpy hold. Make a move to get into the overhanging crack. Reach up and get some locks, and then a couple of hand jams and grab the jugs. Climb up through sandy-ish terrain, or climb down a couple moves and drop.

 Problem is very good, albeit a bit tortorous on the skin. However, if you're looking for some solid crackclimbing for a few moves, definitely get on this problem.
content.protection: A couple of pads. Spotter, maybe.
content.location: 10ish feet left of Mother Thrutch. Near the Dragon corridor.

content.description: Easy, one move wonder crack problem.
content.location: In the corridor area. The trail will come right by it. Trust me, you won't miss this beautiful line.

content.description: Stand start on good pockets and climb up through dishes and slopers to the point of the boulder.  Good footwork is key on this.
content.location: ** LOCATED ON THE 18th FAIRWAY and ONLY CLIMBABLE DURING STONE FORT COMP!!!  Located on the rounded boulder adjacent to the El Camino Boulder.  It is the first problem on L as you enter the El Camino corridor.

content.description: Just to the right of "Needless Things."  Stand start at the bottom and angle up and right, following obvious rightward crack.
content.location: Front Area: Fire Crack Boulder: Just right of "Needless Things."

content.description: Sit start on big rail and gain pocket above. Make moves up and left using small crimps and slopers to a V-shaped jug before a high foot to the top. *Down-climb The Cornerstone Boulder on the left or climb to the very top and find a safe downclimb.  **This problem is not in any of the books and I had to do some cleaning, so I'll be claiming it as an  FA, so I can share with everyone on this site and hopefully make it to the next edition of the book along with other even better developed lines out there. Stay tuned for more and let me know what you think about the climb or if you know anyone who has done this problem before. Enjoy!
content.location: This problem is located on the tall slabby face just right of The Cornerstone Boulder which is  between The Spyro Gyro Area and The Bowling Ball Boulder.

content.description: Obvious center fist-sized crack on Castle Wall. Can be wet inside. Probably best option for downclimbing routes on this wall.

This little wall is studded with cool grips on solid stone, and makes for a great warm-up spot. There are 4 or 5 lines, with lots of opportunity for eliminates, traverses, creativity, or just 4 or 5 straight up lines.   

  Left to right, the difficulties are roughly: v1, v0, v1, v2, v1, but they do tend to blend, and if you start in a couple of spots, you might be able to do some v3 moves.  

  The wall is pretty tall - around 40 feet, but you just climb up to the huge jugs at 10' and either traverse left to the easiest exit, or down climb. 

  Once you've done these, there are great problems of all difficulty levels within a 1 minute walk.
content.protection: 1 pad. There are 2 trees in the landing zone for some of the lines, so a good spot is helpful, or don't climb between the trees and wall.
content.location: In the Main Area, look for Brian's Brain v1, also the wall with Life Is Goodlet v6. Cormany Wall is to the right of this face, and forms a 90 degree angle to the Brian's Brain wall.

content.description:
A fun two move problem starting on jugs and moving up to a neat meathook sloper.

 Sit-start with hands on either side of the bulging arete on jugs. Pull on with slabby foot smears and climb straight up.
content.location: This boulder problem is located on a boulder found fifteen yards before entering the corridor that leads to "Now and Zen". It shares the same start as for "The Barrier", but climbs directly up.

content.description: The v2 on the left side of the same face as Shotgun, v6, is totally great. Work through pockets, rails, and a technical for the grade topout. Good stuff.
content.location: Left side of same face as Shotgun, v6. It's an obvious line on the cleanest rock on that side of the face.

content.description:
This gem is only officially climbable during Triple Crown.

 Stand start matched on the sloping arete-like feature. Find a foot and lock-off out left to a good gaston edge. With difficulty get a high foot and match before firing up to a sloper and then heading up and right to mantle.

 A little contrived, but the contrivance makes it a better and more fun line. There are large jugs just left off the gaston that is matched. There is also a large foot rail underneath the gaston edge which is on. Although avoiding it and dynoing to the lip makes it a bit more challenging.

 A good way to climb this problem is to get after it once the golf course closes for the day.
content.location: When crossing from the Super Mario Area to the Back Nine, one can turn around and see this climb visible about 150 yards away on the golf course in the cluster of boulders. To approach it, walk from the Sternum Area past "Left Wing" and "Right Wing" and reach the golf course. Walk left past some slabby boulders and round the corner on the right. This is the first line found.

content.description: This is a linkup that starts on Cleopatra (V8) and climbs into Cinderella (V7).  The rock is beautiful with cool moves, but it's a linkup and an ass-dragger.  The crux may be keeping your feet off the pads.
content.protection: This has a high but easy topout over a boulder, so bring pads and a good spotter.
content.location: On the Cinderella Boulder, just past the old "Main Area"

content.description: A super classic problem marred only by the scrunchy start and wet landing.  After a sit start, small, slopey crimps get you up the difficulties with some creative footwork.  The topout is high, but easy, and you can bail onto a tree if you get scared.
content.location: About 200 yards past the entrance, just after the "corridor" (with Celestial Mechanics and Tristar), the trail will head way down into a stream bed.  Follow the stream uphill to locate a boulder the the stream flows out from under.  The line right above the water on this clean white boulder is Cleopatra.

content.description: Crimp and slab your way up the tall face to the sidepull.  Wrestle with the "elevator doors" and top-out carefully.
content.location: Two Shoes Jack Boulder, just right of Crystal Ball.

content.description: Super classic problem on a nice looking white boulder.  Sit start with a juggy left hand and right hand crimp, then work up the arete to a long reach or dyno on bad crimps.  The topout is high, but easy...have pads and an attentive spotter.
content.location: About 200 yards from the entrance, just past the "Corridor" (with Celestial Mechanics and Tristar), the trail will head down into a stream bed.  Follow the stream uphill to locate a boulder with water flowing out from under it.     The problem is the left arete of this white boulder.

content.description:
Sternum Area - Chronic Boulder 

  Sds @ large rippled sloper, slap up and right to a second sloping hold, rock over and paw your way up the slab using the arête for the right hand. Decend left via a downward trending seem.
Short, fun climb! Sit start on jug, hop up to more great holds to the top. Great warm up route.
content.location: On Daddy Loves Boulder behind the Wave boulder

content.description: Start with right hand on undercling in crack and left hand on sloper around the arete. Work the arete slopers and weird holds on the face to an easy top out. You will immediately know how this problem got it's name.
content.location: Front Area: Turtle Tracks boulder. The Cheese Grater climbs the arete on the left side of the steeper part of the Turtle Tracks boulder.

content.description: Start on the left most side of the crimp rail that extends into Midway. Make your way using bad crimps and poor or non-existent feet to finish on Midway. A lowball traverse sort of line.
content.location: Links into Midway V7. Located behind the Two Shoes Jack boulder, near Shotgun.

content.description:
Stand start with a high left gaston and a high right undercling. Find a way to establish yourself on the wall and reach the only other feature on the wall: a gently curving right-facing sidepull. Pick a good spot on the sidepull, get a high foot, and fire to the lip.  

  Traverse the ledge to the right to get down. 

  Jimmy Webb climbed this from a lower start (matched on the undercling), giving it V9.
content.protection: A pad or two and a spotter. The landing is perfect.
content.location: Just left of Tristar, in the same alcove as Dragon Lady in what the guidebook calls the Main Area.

content.description: Start in the vacant cavity and slap to the top on slopers and smears. Classic southern top out.
content.location: Fairway boulders.

content.description: A classic one move wonder.  Match the single obvious diagonal crimp at chest height on the prow of the rock.  Paste feet against the wall on the only usable ripple, and huck for the lip.

Stand start with no hands. Pick a foothold, stand up on it, and grab the shallow sloper crease. Move to the obvious jug from there. The top of it is usually wet, so I'm making it a drop down problem. Topping it would probably add another grade or two. *Very similar to Watermelon Slab in the area, hence the name.This entire boulder is not in any of the books and its hard to believe that it hasn't been climbed before, however, there's no information on any of the beta sites about the lines I put up, so I'll be claiming them as FA's, so I can share with everyone on this site and hopefully make it to the next edition of the book along with other even better developed lines out there. Stay tuned for more and let me know what you think about the climb or if you know anyone who has done this problem before. Enjoy!
content.location: This problem is located on the blank boulder located left of Space and Odyssey. and across from Two Shoes Jack.

content.description: Stand start with left hand on first bump from Kingpin, just above the side pull. Smear and bump your hands up arete and press it out.
content.location: just right us Kingpin on Bowling ball boulder.

content.description: Stand start the slab with a large jug flake and a good foot. Press up onto the wall and climb up large features and holds till about the halfway mark. Once here, the holds become less great and more spaced. Make a long reach up to a cup-like hold in a runnel then figure out how to gain some high feet. Continue up a few more moves and make another long reach to a good meathook at the top of the runnel.Once here, the slab mellows out more but there are not any topout jugs unless heading further right. Even on these jugs, it is an exciting finish high off the deck.
content.location: The Back Nine. This problem climbs the middle of the highball face on the boulder just past the classic "Instinct".

content.description: The brother to Deception.  Basically just an alternate start.  For tall folks, I think the grade is the same or possibly easier.  Start 4' right of Deception on  holds in a vertical crack like feature.  A few tense moves with tiny feet get you to the horizontal and into the same topout as Deception.
content.protection: fairly high with challenging moves at 12-15'.  And flat holds, not jugs on the topout.  Pad adequately

content.description: Stand start at good holds near the middle of the wall. Move up and left to a topout with a few options.
content.location: Located just outside the Tristar/Dragon Boulder alcove in the Main Area.

content.description: This is a challenging problem with some great and interesting movement!Stand start at the base of the dihedral-like feature with a low left hand gaston and a positive right hand sidepull pinch/ crimp just to the right. Move up a series of ear-like pinches and gastons on some poor feet, latch a cool hold out left, then make a big move to the lip!The holds are all positive and good rock, but the lip jug is a bit cursed.
content.protection: 2-3 pads and a spotter. The climb is over a slab and there is a drop under the climb which could make the climber slide down a few additional feet to ground level.
content.location: This awesome problem is found on the same boulder at "Fatigue Syndrome", "Left Wing" and "Fight Club".It is located a few feet left of "Fight Club" and climbs the obvious well cleaned directional gaston and sidepulling ears.Starting as for "Fight Night" seems like it may be possible around V11-12.

content.description: Slap up arete to left of tree.  Hard mantle finish
content.location: In the Entrance Area, on the "Bowling Ball" boulder, adjacent to the Firecrack boulder.

content.description: Start on a good pocket just right of a crack and move right through slopey pods and pockets to a jug at the base of the arete.  Then head up the arete to an easy but delicate topout.
content.location: In the Back Nine.  One of the first boulder problems you encounter.  From the rock steps that you take off the green, walk about 50 feet and take an obvious trail to the right towards the golf course.

content.description: You've walked past this a hundred times on your way back to ️Spanky. Lowball traverse on the Phillis Fury boulders. Star on the far left and traverses the face (staying 1. Under the obvious break on sharp crimps and 2. Finishing up Sidewinder for full V points) ending on the far right. Using the break and/or exiting the V0 early finish earns you nothing but distain.
"Sketchy" The tall red face which faces the trail as you enter the boulders is a cool problem. Stand start in the middle and follow edges and underclings up to the roundy top out.
content.location: On the brain boulder

content.description: Start on the thin rail down and left from the stand start.
Start with both hands on a sloping ledge.  Mantle to gain left hand crimp.  Move through a blank face to a good side pull and jugs, top out.
content.location: On the Blunt arete right of "Pinch the Loaf" on the Mystery machine boulder.

content.description:
The leftmost of the 3 v0s on the back of the Mystery Machine boulder. These three climbs are great first of the day warm ups. Good for beginners, too. Easy up, easy down-climb on the corner. Good stuff.  

  I start this one from the left rail that is also the starting point of the Boogie Man-tle (traverse right into the crack). There is also a reachy straight up v0 that starts on the cracky feature.
content.location: Back side of the Mystery Machine boulder

content.description: SICK!!  One of the roof problems at LRC, great quality.
content.protection: Several pads and a couple of spotters.

content.description: This highball slab climbs the clean white East face of the Tristar boulder.  Begin near the right side of the face, just right of a tree, pull a crux slab move about 6 feet up, ending at a good jug at about 12 feet.  Drop/down-climb from here, or continue up on much easier terrain to the high summit of the boulder.
content.location: In the old "Main Area", on the East face of the "Tristar" boulder.

content.description: Short and sweet v0 that is pretty much a grab a jug, paste a foot, and stand up affair. Not bad for what it is, though. And when you include it with the others on this face, it makes up part of a nice little warm up circuit.
content.protection: 1 pad. Over a log, best not to fall, probably.
content.location: On the Mystery Groove boulder, on the uphill face, directly across from Storming the Castle.

content.description: Used to go at V9 before people began using the crack for starting feet. Start low on positive crimps and move up through rounded pockets. Make "blind" stab up and left for sloping crimp, finish directly up, do not traverse right into Diesel power finsh.
content.location: Around the corner from Fromundathunda/Thundafromundajust and past Fat Cat. On the same boulder as the Tooth Fairy problems just to the left of Diesel Power.

content.description: Though it's very low to the ground, this is not as ass-draggy as you might think.  The footholds are quite good, which makes it easy to keep off the ground.  Start way on the right on a large slopey ledge, then make several moves left towards the low crimp rail on Cyclops, finishing up it.  With so many moves, this climbs more like a route than a boulder problem, and the biggest challenge may be overcoming the pump.
content.location: In the "Back Nine" area, on the "Cyclops" boulder.  Follow the trail past Deception, White Trash and the Mono doigt walls to this boulder with a conspicuous softball-sized cyclops eye about 8 feet up.

content.description: ONLY CLIMBABLE DURING THE STONE FORT COMPETITION. Begin in the low vertical break and climb up the bulging arete.
content.location: Black Planet Boulder

content.description: Establish on easy slab to sloping edges in cracks up high. Rock over on good feet to an easy top out.  Don’t fall on this one.
content.location: Left of Green Label on the Slice and Dice boulder.

content.description: Start on the low sidepulls and climb up until you can find the jug on the lip, throw a toe on the mini crimp and PUSH
content.location: To the far left of Genghis Khan till you see a big fin, right of that is Black Carpet.

content.description: Sit start on crimps in horizontal break. Climb straight up through positive holds to slopey but good topout.
content.location: Downhill to the right of Chronic towards Bonesaw

content.description: A classic problem with very sustained climbing. It's hard to say what the crux move is.  Start matched on a well-chalked third-pad crimp under the roof.  Make a big move out left to a big edge, then move back right over the lip and onto the face above.
content.location: In the "Back Nine" area, on the "Biggie Shorty" boulder. To get here, walk to the right of the "Graham Crackers" boulder, then immediately turn left behind it, into a corridor leading to the BS boulder. This problem is in the back, on the right.

content.description: Adds a sloper traverse to the brutal topout of Fish Market. Start on the same holds as you use for Soapmakers v2 (edges, if memory serves), and work your way straight up to some slopers. Power will get you through the tough moves quickly, or you can laboriously tic tac your way across the slopers at the lip to the left, until you hit the topout slopers of Fish Market. Then finish on that.
content.location: Fish Market boulder. Start down and right, work up into Fish Market finish.

content.description: Start with right hand on a decent crimp blob and left on a sloper. Climb straight up to a high topout using good edges. Chalk up and mantle it out.
content.protection: A couple pads and a spotter would be nice.
content.location: On the Jerry's Kids boulder in the Jungle Gym area. Just to the left of Jerry's Kids V7.

content.description:
Start low on an undercling crack in a horizontal crack below an overhaning arete feature.  Reach up to slopers and a good edge.  Make a tough move to a comfy finger lock, bump up to a small horn and move right to a good crack and a slightly unsettling topout. 

  Good for anyone looking for skin-friendly, decent holds on a steep wall.
content.protection: The uneven landing requires at least two pads and a good spot if you aren't solid at the grade.
content.location: On Super Mario Boulder on opposite side from Super Mario.  Right most route on that side.

content.description: Classic roof problem at Stone Fort. Stand start at the jug under the roof. Climb the roof out and left. Encounter a hard section at the lip. Climb up and either finish left, stepping off onto the block, or top-out for full credit.
content.protection: Large boulders make the landing uneven, plus the climb has committing moves. Plenty of pads and a good spot are helpful.
content.location: The Hidden Area. Bedwetters is located on the same boulder as Pancake Mantle and Steam Roller. Just walk around to the left for the easiest approach.

content.description:
Powerful compression on slopers that are barely holdable, this problem could be harder than its neighbour, "Robbing the Toothfairy". 

 Sit-start on the jug horizontal to the left of the tree. From here, pull on and cross up right-hand to a bad sloper in the black water-groove. Smack out to the arete with the left-hand and squeeze the juice out of the block. Find the good left toe, then continue smacking up the polished arete and the sloping water groove for the right. A few desperate moves lead to jugs on the lip of the boulder. 

 This line flows nicely when it comes together, and it is a natural sit-start that is rarely done. Breaking the beta and escaping out right into the water-groove seems possible, but that would be cheating yourself. To climb the water-groove, check out "Get Your Groove On" which has recently been cleaned, and climb directly up from the same start.
content.location:
This problem is located on the same boulder as "Diesel Power" and "The Toothfairy". Follow the main trail past the entrance blocks and hike through a section of the trail where the rocks run out. This will be the next large boulder that the trail encounters.

 This problem climbs from the jug horizontal up and slightly left over a smaller, but flat boulder, which then drops off several feet to the trail.

content.description: Stand start the giant bulging arête with the right hand out right in a black water groove. Pull onto the wall and make some hard compression moves up the slopey polished arête over a slightly sketchy landing.
content.location: This Boulder is on the Blind Spot Boulder which lies adjacent to the Fromundathunda Boulder. It is located right on the "Express Trail" and the two boulders create a sort of Corridor . This problem lies on the left side of the large wall.

content.description:
A rad lowball that is slightly contrived but flows well once unlocked. Sit start on a large left-hand jug sidepull and a good right-hand sidepull pocket around the bulging arete. (This is the same start as for "Conway Twitty Twister")  Pull on to the wall and move right to pockets and a sweet sloping pinch. Continue moving right with a hard move to a sloper and then reach for a good hold in the water groove. 

 Technical climbing on good feet and pretty good holds.
content.location: This boulder problem is located in the "Moss Man Area" and lies on the boulder next to "Slow Rock Fury".

content.description: A magnificent bullet-hard problem. Stand start at the base of a crescent shaped rail. Pull on with a right foot smear and reach up right hand to a weird gaston-like hold on the crescent rail, get a high left foot on the rail. Toe down with all the core you have and then some. Make a hard move up to a sloping left-hand crimp at the top of the crescent rail. From here flip the right hand down to a sloping undercling and get a high right foot. From here execute a huge move with the right hand up to a small incut crimp about four feet above the left hand. Once you have snagged this little crimp, grab a jug out left and campus over and top out.
content.location: While looking at "Deception"  look 25 feet left. Can't miss it.

content.description: Start on the long flat rail, same as "Art of the Vogi". Make moves going left on big flakes and jugs. A hard move to gain the slab section leads to an easy finish.
content.protection: A couple of pads and a good spot will keep you safe.
content.location: Art of the Vogi Boulder, Front Area

content.description: One of the steep problems at LRC. Lip is the crux.

Start left hand on a slopey sidepull and right on a thigh-high sidepull.  Using the right side of the Fire Crack Flake for your feet, pull on the wall, make a subtle move to a sidepull and follow edges and an undercling to an easy topout. 

  Good problem to work alone with one pad.  Cold conditions help.   

  It's V6 if you start left hand on the slopey sidepull and right on the second sidepull- skipping the first move.
content.location: Just right of the Fire Crack Flake.

content.description: V6 start of Aneardon Low. Start left hand on slopey sidepull and right on the second sidepull- skipping the first move.
content.location: Right of Fire Crack Flake.

content.description: Unique full body compression involved on this one. Start standing with a left hand slopey dish and right hand on a bigger pocket undercling down and right. Get a bomber toe hook on the arete and figure out how to reach the left facing sidepull above before topping out.
content.location: To the right of "Sternum".

content.description: Start matched on a large crimper around the arete with feet posted on either side.  Move up to a sidepull, then a tenuous mantle-ish move into the scoop.  Finish high on jugs.
content.location: The arete to the right of "Deception".  Same beautiful stone, more accessible grade.

content.description: Stand start on the route "Split" and traverse right to top out on the route "Gutter Ball". My friends and I had a lot of fun on this line. It is much like a lighter version of "Slap Happy".
content.location: Bowling Ball Area

content.description: Stone Fort is one of the best areas for bouldering in the Chattanooga Area. It has a large variety of problems and the rock quality is excellent.
